questions.text: Which of the following is associated with CSF otorrhea?

choices.text: Traumatic rupture of the tympanic membrane
Fracture of the roof of the nose

questions.solution:
A battle sign is seen in CSF otorrhea.

Battle sign refers to the retro auricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of the middle cranial fossa following head trauma. It is prominent when there is a fracture of the temporal bone. CSF leak is associated with head trauma and fracture of the temporal bone. It can present as CSF otorrhea or CSF rhinorrhea or both.

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. 
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa. 
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Spontaneous resolution is seen within 14 days. Perioperative fluorescein cisternography is used for identifying the site of leakage. Persistent CSF leaks and large tegmen defects are treated with surgery due to the risk of herniation of the meninges and the brain.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double target sign or Halo sign or Target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.
  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

Note: Reservoir sign is also seen in acute mastoiditis/ coalescent mastoiditis where mastoid acts as a reservoir of pus and pus reappear in EAC immediately after cleaning.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a history of facial edema that has now progressed to total body swelling involving the face, abdomen, scrotum, and feet. Urinalysis revealed protein 4+ and a urine protein:creatinine ratio of 3. What is the initial treatment of choice for this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and investigations are highly suggestive of minimal change nephrotic syndrome and the initial treatment of choice is corticosteroids such as prednisolone.

Minimal change nephrotic syndrome is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome. It is seen in ages 2-6 years. Its features include heavy proteinuria, oedema, hypoalbuminemia and hyperlipidemia. They may be asymptomatic or can present with peripheral edema. Renal biopsy is not required for confirmation and treatment can be initiated if the child fits the standard clinical picture of nephrotic syndrome.

They show excellent response to steroid therapy with prednisone or prednisolone. A daily dose of 2mg/kg (max 60mg) for 6 weeks followed by an alternate day dose of 1.5mg/kg (max 40mg) for the next 6-8 weeks is recommended.

Alternative drugs used in steroid-dependent patients, frequent relapsers, steroid-resistant patients, and those with severe corticosteroid toxicity are as follows:

  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Calcineurin inhibitors: Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus
  • Mycophenolate
  • Levamisole
  • Rituximab (chimeric monoclonal antibody against CD20)

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describes the sensation as a curtain being drawn over his affected eye. In addition, 7 days ago the patient noticed what he described as flashing lights and floaters. He gives a history of having cataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. A B-scan image of his left eye is shown below. What could be his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the B-scan suggest a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. It is due to the accumulation of fluid between neurosensory retina(NSR) and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to a retinal tear.

Definition of retinal detachment: The separation of the neurosensory retina from the RPE.

Types of Retinal detachment:

A. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment- fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina.

  • Causes:
    • High myopes
    • Retinoschisis-splitting of neurosensory retina plus vitreous degeneration
      • Typical retinoschisis-split at the level of the outer plexiform layer
      • Atypical retinoschisis-split at the level of the nerve fiber layer
    • Trauma
    • Pseudophakia
    • Aphakia
  • The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear.
  • The most dangerous location of retinal break is the supero-temporal retina. 
  • Clinical features
    • Photopsia-flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break
    • Floaters
    • Visual field defect- a black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Hypotony- as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE.
    • Shafers sign-pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations.
  • Treatment
    • Prophylactic laser barrage
    • Scleral buckling
    • Pneumatic retinopexy
    • Pars plana vitrectomy 

B. Tractional retinal detachment: Fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. 

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Central retinal venous occlusion
    • Eales disease
    • Retinopathy of Prematurity(ROP)
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in configuration. No breaks are seen
  • Treatment
    • Pars plana vitrectomy with endo photocoagulation. 

C. Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative fluid from the choroid, collects in the subretinal space leading to retinal detachment.

  • Causes
    • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
    • Choroidal tumours like melanoma
    • Toxaemia of pregnancy
    • Malignant hypertension
    • Coats disease
  • Clinical features
    • Floaters due to vitritis but no photopsia
    • Visual field defect
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break is seen.
    • Shifting fluid is seen.
  • Treatment
    • Systemic steroids
    • Treatment of the cause

 The image below shows a fundus which reveals retinal detachment inferiorly from 3-9 o'clock with a tear at 3:30

questions.text: The X-Ray of a middle aged man showed multiple lytic lesions following which a urine examination was done. The sample revealed Bence Jones proteins. Which is the most common immunoglobulin associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario consisting of multiple lytic bony lesions and Bence Jones proteins indicates multiple myeloma.  Most myelomas are associated with more than 3 g/dL of serum Ig and/or more than 6 mg/dL of urine Bence Jones protein. The most common monoclonal Immunoglobulin (M protein) is IgG followed by IgA.

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors involving the axial skeleton. The bones most commonly affected in descending order of frequency are the vertebral column, ribs, skull, pelvis, femur, clavicle, and scapula. 

Morphology:

  • Malignant plasma cells have a perinuclear clearing due to a prominent golgi apparatus and an eccentrically placed nucleus.
  • Relatively normal-appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and a prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.
  • Other cytologic variants include flame cells, Mott cells.
  • Flame cells have fiery red cytoplasm, Mott cells contain multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets, a variety of other inclusions, including fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules. The globular inclusions are referred to as Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) or Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).
  • Rouleaux formation is characteristic but not specific. High levels of M protein in the blood causes red cells to stick to one another in linear arrays in smears leading to rouleaux formation.

Image showing peripheral smear of multiple myeloma:

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

  • Serum β2-microglobulin. It is the single most powerful predictor
  • Deletion of 17pITP53 sequences and the translocations t(14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • High degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

The clinicopathologic diagnosis of multiple myeloma can be done based on the identification of clonal plasma cells in the marrow and the presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia, and bone lesions).

Other options:

A) Ig A is not the most common immunoglobulin associated with the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. While Ig A can be involved in some cases, Ig G is the most frequently observed immunoglobulin in this context.

B) Ig D is not commonly associated with the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. Bence Jones proteins are typically composed of monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains, and Ig D is not commonly involved in plasma cell disorders such as multiple myeloma.

D) Ig M is not the most common immunoglobulin associated with the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine. While Ig M can be involved in certain plasma cell disorders, Ig G is the most frequently observed immunoglobulin associated with Bence Jones proteins.

Related Pearl: International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with history of dysphagia, halitosis and aspiration pneumonia. A barium swallow was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the collection of contrast in a pouch-like structure, which favours the diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum.

Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum resulting from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian), an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibres of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibres of the lower inferior constrictor (At the level of the hypopharynx, just proximal to the upper oesophagal sphincter). This phenomenon may lead to the creation of a sac with a narrow neck that can trap liquid and food. The distended sac may compress the cervical oesophagus.

Clinical presentation:         

The entrapment of liquid and/or food within the diverticulum may result in:

  • Globus sensation
  • Dysphagia
  • Halitosis
  • Regurgitation
  • Aspiration pneumonia

Diagnosis is by Barium swallow studies and video laryngoscopy.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: Which of the following combination of cylindrical lenses can be used to treat with-the-rule astigmatism?
questions.solution:
- 3.00 DC x 180, + 1.00 DC x 90 can be used to correct with-the-rule astigmatism.

In with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is steeper than the horizontal meridian. Hence, to make up for this, we need a combination of cylindrical lenses with relatively greater power in the horizontal meridian than the vertical meridian.

Before considering the options, also remember that a cylinder aligned along the horizontal meridian (180 axis) has action in the vertical meridian and vice versa.

In option A, the cylinder acting along the horizontal meridian (- 3.00 DC x 90) has lesser power than the one acting along the vertical meridian (+ 5.00 DC x 180). This is also the case with options B and C.  

Only option D has a cylinder with greater power along the horizontal meridian ( +1.00 DC x 90) compared to the vertical meridian (- 3.00 DC x 180). Hence, option D is the answer.

 Alternative method:

This method involves the use of the optical cross technique

STEP 1:

  • Frame the optical cross with the given powers in their respective meridians.
  • While framing the optical cross, the power which is given in 180 needs to marked in 90 and vice versa.

For example, option A has + 5.00 DC x 180, - 3.00 DC x 90 which means the eye gets a correction of + 5.00 in vertical meridian (i.e in 90 degree) and correction of - 3.00 in horizontal meridian (i.e in 180 degree). Keeping this in mind, if one frames the optical crosses for the given options, the end image would be as given below  

 

 STEP 2:

Now we need to interpret the optical crosses to find which meridian is steeper with certain hints.

  • If the power in one axis is ‘+’ and the power in other axis is ‘-’, then the axis with ‘-’ power is steeper.
  • If powers in both the axis are ‘-’, then the higher number of the two will be steeper.
  • If powers in both the axis are ‘+’, then the lower number of the two will be steeper.

STEP 3:

Applying these hints to the options will give option D as with-the-rule astigmatism.

questions.text: A farmer is brought to the hospital 8 hours later, following a snake bite. He complained of headache, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, dizziness, vertigo, and multiple episodes of vomiting since the bite. He has signs of respiratory depression and a pulse <50. The local wound showed mild swelling and blistering. There are no apparent bleeding manifestations. He was administered 10 vials of antivenom. Which of the following is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a neurotoxic snake bite. Since this patient has already passed 8 hours without any bleeding manifestations, the bite of a hemotoxic snake is unlikely and the better management would be to address his neurotoxic symptoms with the administration of neostigmine with atropine.

The neurotoxic symptoms are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs, such as neostigmine. Atropine is administered to counter the muscarinic side effects of neostigmine. 

Neurotoxic symptoms include: 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Perioral paraesthesia (tingling sensation around the mouth)
  • Vomiting
  • Dizziness
  • Vertigo
  • Hyperacusis
  • Gooseflesh
  • Hypersalivation

Respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles, at this stage or later. If it progresses to paralysis, it initially presents with ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia, which may appear between a few minutes after the bite or after some hours.

ASV(Anti Snake Venom) is the mainstay of snakebite treatment. Neurotoxicity effects may wear off spontaneously in about a week and are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase. Atropine can be used in the management of venom that acts postsynaptically. Ventilatory support is provided in cases complicated with severe respiratory depression, in the event of failure of other measures of management. 

ASV used in India is effective against:

  • Cobra
  • Common krait
  • Russel viper
  • Saw scaled viper

Measures that can be done in the case of snakebite:

  • Apply firm pressure over the bitten area, which delays the absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis
  • Clean the wound with soap and water, or iodine and cover it with a sterile dressing 
  • Immediately apply a broad firm bandage (Sutherland wrap) on the bitten area and around the limb. As much of the limb should be bandaged as possible. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. 
  • In bites on the trunk, head, or neck, apply firm pressure over the bitten area
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting

Measures contraindicated in the case of snakebite:

  • Suction and incision of the wound
  • Electric shock treatment of wound site
  • Application of tourniquets because they obstruct arterial flow and cause ischemia
  • Ice water immersion of the bitten limb

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with severe headache, photophobia and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilledema and nuchal rigidity was present. Kernig's and Brudzinski signs were positive.  CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is
questions.solution:
History and physical examination findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The given image shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci which is  Neisseria meningitidis.

Fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs) in a child, with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis.

Pathogenesis & clinical features:

  • The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili. From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages. 
  • Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

CSF findings in different types of meningitis

Parameter/ Meningitis Bacterial  Tubercular  Viral 
CSF pressure Raised Raised Raised
Appearance Turbid Clear (cob-web formation) Clear
Glucose Decreased Decreased Normal
Protein High Very high slightly high
Cells Neutrophils Lymphocytes Lymphocytes
  • All patients admitted to the hospital with meningitis should be placed on standard precautions.
  • Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy. 
  • Chemoprophylaxis is indicated for the household and close contacts. The preferred antibiotics are rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone.

Option a: Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate. H. influenzae b grows on chocolate agar (which supplies necessary nutrients from lysed red blood cells) or as satellite colonies surrounding β-hemolytic colonies of S. aureus on blood agar.

Option c: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive, capsulated, flame-shaped or lanceolate-shaped diplococcus.

Option d: Listeria monocytogenes is a gram positive bacillus.

Related Pearl: Comparison between Meningococci and Gonococci

GONOCOCCUS MENINGOCOCCUS
Not capsulated Capsulated
Only Glucose fermented Glucose and Maltose fermented
Kidney shaped Lens/half-moon shaped
Exist predominantly in intracellular form Exist in both intra and extracellular form
Sexually or perinatally transmitted Spread via Respiratory or oral secretions
Usually possess plasmids,coding for drug resistance Rarely have plasmids
No vaccine due to antigenic variation of pilus proteins Capsule based Polysaccharide and conjugate vaccine available(Except for Type B for which Subcapsular antigen-based vaccine is available)

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance?
questions.solution:
Sickle cell anemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the T-to-A point mutation in the sixth codon of the β-globin gene. This results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Painful bone crisis- hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    • Adolescence or early adulthood- autosplenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

 The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled RBCs on peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike.

Disease-modifying drugs such as hydroxyurea can be given to patients with sickle cell anemia since it reduces the incidence of adverse vaso-occlusive vents. Blood transfusions are used to treat and prevent complications of sickle cell disease, including preparation for surgery, symptomatic anemia, acute stroke, multi-organ failure and acute chest syndrome

Other options:

Option B: G6PD deficiency - X linked recessive

Option C: Marfan’s syndrome - Autosomal dominant

Option D: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome - X-linked recessive

 

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

In this question,

  • Nutritional status (nourished or malnourished) is a qualitative measure.
  • Residence (Urban or rural) is again a qualitative measure.
  • Further, only these TWO variables are being compared. Therefore, the chi-square test is the most appropriate test of significance.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increase.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test can also be used.

Other options:

Option B: The paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. If a study were to compare BP in a group of patients before and after treatment, then paired t-test would be used. It is also a test done for quantitative variables.

Option C: Standard error of the mean measures how much discrepancy is likely in a sample's mean compared with the population mean. It is not a test for statistical significance.

Option D: The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between means of two or more than two groups. Hence it is used in studies with quantitative data. If a study was done to compare the heights of boys in different classes in a school, ANOVA would be used.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese Encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

World mosquito day is celebrated annually on August 20 to create awareness about mosquito-borne diseases. It is a commemoration of a British doctor, Sir Ronald Ross’s discovery in 1897 that ‘female mosquitoes transmit malaria between humans’.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Charateristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
EggsUsually 100-250. This stage lasts 1 – 2 days. Laid singly; boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star shaped clusters.
Larval stageThis stage lasts for 5 -7 days.

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Stripped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artifical collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and legs. 

 

 

  • Culex mosquito, they keep their bodies horizontal while feeding:

 

  • Anopheles mosquito as seen in the image below, they tend to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high:

 

  • Aedes mosquito (aegypti), as seen in the image below, their bodies are striped:

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is responsible for the following natural process?
questions.solution:
Oxytocin helps in the ejection of milk by myoepithelial contraction which can be felt as cramps.

     Functions of oxytocin are:

  • Milk ejection (Myoepithelial contraction)
  • ADH like action in high doses (reduces urine output)
  • Uterine contraction

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient came with complaints of blurring of vision, photophobia, and pain in the eye. He also has congestion of the eyes and joint pain. All ocular complaints are unilateral. Which of the following major histocompatibility complexes (MHC) can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis here is anterior uveitis seen in ankylosing spondylitis and the major histocompatibility complex associated with this condition is  HLA B27.

HLA B27 is positive in the following conditions:

  • Psoriatic spondylitis
  • Reactive arthritis due to Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, Chlamydia
  • Acute anterior uveitis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis

 Anterior uveitis: Involvement of Iris

  • Most common symptom: Photophobia
  • Most common sign: Cells in Anterior Chamber

Intermediate Uveitis: Involvement of Pars plana and peripheral part of the retina and the underlying choroid.

  • Most common symptom: Floaters
  • Sign: Snowball opacities & snow banking. Seen in pars plana > ora serrata (q)
  • Most Common complication of Pars planitis 
  • Posterior Subcapsular Cataract.

Posterior uveitis: Involvement of Choroid

  • Most Common Symptom: Floaters
  • Most Common cause of visual loss: Cystoid Macular edema

Other options:

HLA B51- Behcet disease

HLA B47- Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

HLA B57- Abacavir Hypersensitivity

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with frequent headaches. Investigation reveals raised intracranial pressure and the presence of a dural-based tumor. Which of the following histological findings correlate with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a dural-based tumor presenting with headaches and raised intracranial pressure is most likely a meningioma and they have psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells on histopathological examination.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.

  • Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.
  • Prior radiation therapy to the head and neck, typically is a risk factor.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is the loss of chromosome 22, especially the long arm (22q).
  • Meningiomas are a common lesion in the setting of NF2 (multiple sites, especially in association with acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.
  • The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated.
  • They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura. This form is commonly associated with hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone.
  • The lesions may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies.

Psammoma bodies are shown below:

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, choroid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

Option A: Fried egg appearance of cells refers to cells with clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus. Fried egg appearance in pathology are:

  • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
  • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
  • Seminoma/Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

Option B: Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes with arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen can be seen in retinoblastoma.

Option D: In medulloblastoma, tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neurophil can be seen.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 70-year- old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted in hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Her temperature was 38.8 degrees. Her blood reports revealed a Hb level of 12g/dl; WBC count of 18,000/mm3; CRP of 160mg/l. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with diarrhoea following antibiotic administration is suggestive of pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhoea in nosocomial infections. It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhoea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to the colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis.

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals a characteristic appearance, with erythema, white plaques, or an adherent pseudomembrane.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in the stool are used as they are both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole, and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral Vancomycin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral Vancomycin
Severe, Complicated (Shock, Ileus, Toxic Megacolon) Oral Vancomycin + IV Metronidazole ± Rectal Vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT)

Fidaxomicin is an alternative in all cases. Metronidazole is now reserved for non-severe infections in settings where access to first-line drugs is limited or cost is an issue. 

Recent update: Harrison's 20th edition recommends the use of vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes which are mild to moderate in severity. Metronidazole is recommended only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin are not accessible. Oral metronidazole is less effective than the other options and may necessitate a longer treatment course for response.

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes for Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: Maple syrup urine disease is due to a defect in which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is due to deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH).

Leucine, isoleucine, and valine are the 3 essential amino acids, which are branched-chain amino acids. Their decarboxylation is accomplished by BCKDH using thiamine (vitamin B1) pyrophosphate as a coenzyme.

Leucine is metabolized by BCAA aminotransferase to α-ketoisocaproic acid, which leads to the disrupted metabolism of neurotransmitters and amino acids (glutamate, GABA, glutamine, alanine, and aspartate). α-Ketoisocaproic acid can reversibly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation and result in cerebral lactic acidosis. Collectively, these processes are detrimental to the normal function of neurons and glia, clinically manifesting as encephalopathy and brain edema and referred to as leucinosis.

Treatment options include hemodialysis, restricting dietary substances, thiamine for milder forms, and orthotopic liver transplant.

Other options:

B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase is involved in the breakdown of isovaleryl-CoA, a compound derived from the metabolism of the amino acid leucine. Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase is associated with a different metabolic disorder called isovaleric acidemia, but not maple syrup urine disease.

C. Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis, a process by which glucose is synthesized from non-carbohydrate sources. Deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase results in a different metabolic disorder known as pyruvate carboxylase deficiency, but it is not associated with maple syrup urine disease.

D. Acetyl CoA carboxylase: Acetyl CoA carboxylase is an enzyme involved in fatty acid synthesis. Deficiency of acetyl CoA carboxylase can lead to a different condition called malonyl-CoA decarboxylase deficiency, but it is not related to maple syrup urine disease.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This patient has symptoms of ptosis, progressive weakness, and excessive fatiguability which improves with neostigmine. 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness.

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial nerve junctions are affected leading to weakness in the lids and extraocular muscles causing diplopia, ptosis in the early stages. Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling, weakness in chewing and swallowing, speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of the palate and tongue.
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, neuromyelitis optics, systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increases transmission)
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • The repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium and neostigmine are acetylcholinesterase inhibitors. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission. The same effect is seen with 

Treatment:

  • Anticholinesterase drugs - Pyridostigmine.
  • Thymectomy.
  • Immunosuppression therapy with glucocorticoids, azathioprine, tacrolimus, rituximab, etc.
  • Plasmapheresis and intravenous immunoglobulin.

Other options:

Option B: Huntington's disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and anticipation. Neostigmine has no effect on it.

Option C: ALS is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. The pathologic hallmark of ALS includes the involvement of lower motor neurons of the ventral/ anterior horn of the spinal cord, cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles, and the afferent corticospinal upper motor neurons in layer five of the motor cortex. Neostigmine has no effect on it.

Option D: The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO).Neostigmine has no effect on it.

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical ‘swallow tails’. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as a/an ___________________
questions.solution:
The characteristics described are consistent with that of a lacerated wound

The characteristics of a lacerated wound:

The margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails.

The edges of the laceration may indicate a direction, in which the blow or force was applied. Depth of the wound shows bridges of irregularly torn fibrous tissue, blood vessels, and nerves and can be soiled by mud, sand, glass, brick particles, vegetation, machine oils, hair, or fibers. These materials embedded in the wound are of great medicolegal value.

Lacerated wounds do not bleed much as the vessels are crushed and torn, thus facilitating hemostasis. The exception to this is injuries to the scalp, where temporal arteries may bleed freely as they are firmly bound and unable to contract. Lacerations over the hairy areas will show hair bulbs crushed and buried into the depth of the wound. Because of the crushing and tearing nature of the production of lacerations, there can be associated abrasion or bruising.

 Swallow tail in a Lacerated wound

 

Fishtails - These may be seen in stab wounds where the skin splits at the corner. 

Chop wounds: called because of the action in which they are produced. Depending on the type of instrument, they may resemble an incised or a lacerated wound. The shape of the wound may give clues to the type of weapon. For example, in the given image, the wound resembles an injury produced by a sharp axe. Such wounds may be inflicted with homicidal intent on the skull/scalp. Chop wounds are usually deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with the sharp cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon like an axe, sword, hatchet etc

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the detection of hemosiderin deposits?
questions.solution:
Perl's prussian blue stain is used to detect hemosiderin deposits.

Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived granular pigment that is golden-yellow to brown. It accumulates in the tissues when there is a local or systemic excess of iron.

Iron is normally stored within cells in association with the protein apoferritin, forming ferritin micelles. Large aggregates of these micelles are hemosiderin deposits seen both in light and electron microscopy. 

Image 1: Hemosiderin deposits in tissue

Image 2: Prussian blue staining of hemosiderin

*Note: Iron dispersed in the cytoplasm is seen in electron microscopy as ferritin micelles.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male has been diagnosed with a condition due to a DNA repair gene defect. He is having hyperpigmentation on the skin and high risk for the development of skin cancers as per the physician. Which of the following mechanisms is likely to be defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical findings is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair where there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.  

Important clinical features are:

Intense cutaneous photosensitivity, xerosis, poikiloderma, actinic keratosis, acute burning under minimal sun exposure, erythemas, hyperpigmented lentiginous macules, and malignant lesions in sun-exposed areas, including basocellular carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma.  

The final diagnosis of XP can be confirmed by special laboratory tests by examining the DNA damage repair in cells from cultures exposed to ultraviolet radiation. The most common tests are skin biopsy and culture of skin fibroblasts.  

There is no cure for XP. Treatment consists of minimizing exposure to sunlight and regular dermatological care, as well as surgery for recurrent tumors excision. Patients should be followed up every 3 months.

Genetic counseling is important in a family that has an affected child and is considering having more children.

Other options:

Option A: Nonhomologous End Joining Repair, is involved in repairing double-stranded DNA breaks and is not directly associated with the repair of UV-induced DNA damage.

Option C: DNA Base Excision Repair, primarily addresses small DNA lesions, such as those caused by oxidative damage, rather than the bulky lesions induced by UV radiation.

Option D: DNA Mismatch Repair (MMR) is a cellular mechanism that corrects errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatched nucleotides or small insertions or deletions. MMR plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the genome and preventing the accumulation of mutations. However, in the scenario described, where a 14-year-old male has hyperpigmentation on the skin and an increased risk of skin cancers, a DNA Mismatch Repair defect is not the most likely mechanism involved.

questions.text: The below image is of a femur bone.Which of the following muscles is attached to "A"?
questions.solution:
The image shows the posterior surface of the right femur and the structure marked "A" is the lesser trochanter where the iliopsoas muscle is attached.

The Iliopsoas comprises of Psoas major and Iliacus. They arise from the lumbar spine and the inner surface of the ilium bone respectively, and insert on the lesser trochanter. The iliopsoas cause flexion of the hip.

The femur can be divided into the proximal femur, shaft, and distal femur.

  • The proximal femur consists of the head, neck, greater and lesser trochanters. The intertrochanteric line is present on the anterior surface at the junction of the neck and shaft of the femur while the intertrochanteric crest is present on the posterior surface. The lesser trochanter is the posteromedial projection of the femur arising posteroinferiorly from the neck-shaft junction.
  • The shaft of the femur consists of linea aspera (bony crest present on the posterior surface), gluteal tuberosity, and pectineal line.
  • The distal femur consists of the medial condyle, lateral condyle, intercondylar fossa, and patellar surface.

The image below shows attachments of various muscles over the posterior surface of the right femur.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a habit of biting his lips and fingers and you observe missing portions of fingers on his left hand. A detailed evaluation reveals delayed developmental milestone.On inquiry, the parents say that two male cousins on the mother's side have similar complaints and have been diagnosed with a genetic disorder. Lab reports reveal hyperuricemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones, positive family history and hyperuricemia is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It occurs due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).

Purines can be converted to nucleoside triphosphates to be reused by the body. This pathway is called the salvage pathway for purines. 

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). This causes increased de novo purine synthesis and excessive amounts of uric acid. 

 

 

The clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements, and hyperuricemia.

Diagnosis is made by deficient HGPRT enzyme activity in the erythrocyte.

The treatment of this condition includes:

  • Allopurinol for hyperuricemia
  • Behavioral management using restraints for self-mutilation

Partial deficiency of HGPRT leads to Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options:

Option A:  Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency results in decreased function of T cells but B cells are normal. This leads to multiple infections, neurologic abnormalities, and autoimmune diseases. 

Option C: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase deficiency results in the accumulation of adenine. This is oxidized to 2,8-dihydroxyadenine which is insoluble. This leads to urinary calculus formation with crystalluria, urinary tract infections, hematuria, and renal failure.

Option D: Adenosine deaminase deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner and is one of the major causes of severe combined immunodeficiency.

Related Pearl: Purine salvage deficiencies: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome and Adenosine deaminase deficiency(SCID)

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency(SCID):

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Self-mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Hyperuricemia 
  • Gout

Treatment:

  • Allopurinol
  • Febuxostat

questions.text: A tall obese person, who is a known hypertensive was recently diagnosed with metabolic syndrome on routine workup. Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Increase in uric acid and insulin
Increase in triglycerides and total cholesterol

questions.solution:
Increase in triglycerides and total cholesterol is seen in patients with metabolic syndrome.

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education program and adult treatment panel III). It includes-

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. On examination, the right ear reveals conductive hearing loss with a dull tympanic membrane. A decreased mobility of the soft palate was also noted. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is nasopharyngeal carcinoma. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking. The commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common)
  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
      • CN VI - squint and diplopia, the most common cranial nerve involved
      • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
      • CN V - reduced corneal reflex (Option B)
      • CN II - exophthalmos (Option D)
      • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
      • Horner’s syndrome
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Gold standard investigation before Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is?
questions.solution:
The gold standard investigation before FESS is a CT scan to rule out other pathologies and for confirmation of diagnosis. CT scan is better than MRI for visualizing bones and their anatomy.

Even while doing surgery, decisions on whether to open the mastoid antrum are based on CT findings and intraoperative findings. FESS is done for failed medical management of rhinosinusitis.

Other indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis that is unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis)
  • Fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball or nasal polypi
  • Antrochoanal polyp
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Endoscopic septoplasty

Advanced nasal endoscopic techniques

  • Removal of benign tumors, e.g. inverted papillomas or angiofibromas.
  • Orbital abscess or cellulitis management.
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy
  • Repair of CSF leak
  • Pituitary surgery
  • Optic nerve decompression
  • Orbital decompression for Graves’ disease
  • Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery)
  • Choanal atresia.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have
questions.solution:
After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the ileum. B12 binds to intrinsic factor, a protein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach, and the complex is absorbed across the ileal mucosa. Hence after ileal resection, there is impaired absorption of vitamin B12.

Clinical features of megaloblastic anemia (cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency):

System Clinical features
Oral

Glossitis

Angular cheilosis
Gastrointestinal

Anorexia

Weight loss

Diarrhea

Constipation
Skin Hyperpigmentation (reversible)
Hematological

Thrombocytopenia

Leucopenia

Ineffective erythropoiesis and unconjugated jaundice
Cardiovascular

Atherosclerosis leading to PVD, CAD (due to elevated homocysteine)
Neurological (only B12)

Peripheral neuropathy

Subacute combined degeneration (degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord)
Pregnancy (only folate)

Recurrent fetal loss

Neural tube defects
Others

Mild fever in severe cases

Psychiatric disturbances

Peripheral smear findings:

  • Macro-ovalocytes are seen.
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • Reticulocyte count is low.
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe.
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, with five or more nuclear lobules.

Bone marrow findings:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors
  • Sieve-like pattern of chromatin of immature precursors (Megaloblasts)
  • Granulocytic precursors display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms
  • Megakaryocytes abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei
  • Derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

questions.text: If the diameter of an artery was found to be reduced to one-third. By what value does the resistance of the artery increase?
questions.solution:
The resistance increases by 81 times.

The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed by the Poiseuille-Hagen formula.

Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula: 

Q =π ΔPr4/8ηL

Where

  • Q is the flow rate
  • π is pie symbol
  • ΔP is the pressure difference
  • r is radius
  • η is viscosity
  • L is length

Also,

Flow rate (Q) = pressure difference (ΔP)/ resistance (R).

Therefore, substituting this in Poiseuille- Hagen formula,

ΔP/ R = π ΔPr4/8ηl

1/R = π r4/8ηl

R = 8ηl/ π r4

Therefore it can be derived that airway resistance is inversely proportional to the radius by the power of four.

In the given question, the diameter is reduced to one-third. So, the radius is also reduced to one-third. Hence, vessel resistance will increase by 34 or 81 times.

With Poiseuille- Hagen formula we might feel that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance. However, the contribution by the smallest airways is very little to the overall total resistance. This is because, the airway branches in each generation exist in parallel rather than in series. As the parallel branching increases, the resistance decreases. (Total cross-sectional diameter of small airways put together is high). Thus the overall resistance of the small airways is very small. Also, airflow velocity decreases substantially as the effective cross-sectional area increases (i.e., the flow becomes laminar).

Other factors affecting airway resistance :

  • Lung volume, as lung volume increases the resistance decreases and vice versa. Lung volume increases the transairway pressure thus increasing the caliber of the airway.
  • Airway mucus, edema, and contraction of bronchial smooth muscle increase the airway resistance. Its clinical application is seen in asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema
  • The density and viscosity of inspired gas also contribute to airway resistance. A gas with more density imparts more resistance.

questions.text: Lysosomal enzymes are present in___?
questions.solution:
Among the following options, lysosomal enzymes are present in the cytoplasm of the cell.

The interior of lysosomes, is more acidic than the rest of the cytoplasm, and external material such as endocytosed bacteria, as well as worn-out cell components, are digested in them. The interior is kept acidic by the action of a proton pump, or H+ ATPase which uses the energy of ATP to move protons from the cytosol up their electrochemical gradient and keep the lysosome relatively acidic, near pH 5.0.

Lysosomes contain over 40 types of hydrolytic enzymes,which are all acid hydrolases and they function best at the acidic pH of the lysosomal compartment. This can be a safety feature; if the lysosomes were to break open and release their contents, the enzymes would not be efficient at the near neutral cytosolic pH 7.2, and thus would not be able to digest cytosolic targets they may encounter. 

When a lysosomal enzyme is congenitally absent, the lysosomes become engorged with the material the enzyme normally degrades and leads to lysosomal storage diseases.e.g Fabry disease caused by a deficiency in α-galactosidase; Gaucher disease caused by a deficiency in glucocerebrosidase; Tay-Sachs disease ,caused by the loss of hexosaminidase A.

Related Pearl: Lysosomal storage diseases

Lysosomal Storage Diseases Enzyme-deficient
Sphingolipidoses
Gaucher disease Glucocerebrosidase
Tay-Sachs disease Hexosaminidase A
Fabry disease α-galactosidase A
Krabbe disease

Galactocerebrosidase

(Galactosylceramidase)
Niemann-Pick disease Sphingomyelinase
Mucopolysaccharidoses  
Hurler syndrome α-L-iduronidase
Hunter syndrome Iduronate-2-sulfatase
Others:
Pompe disease Lysosomal acid α-1,4- glucosidase

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy who is a football player comes to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football on the ground. There is no history of trauma or falls. He gives a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding, unilateral nasal obstruction and denasal speech. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is shown below. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the Holman Miller sign or Antral sign.

The given clinical picture along with a CT scan showing the Holman Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. From here the tumour grows into the:

  • Nasal cavity
  • Nasopharynx
  • Pterygopalatine fossa
  • Pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Infratemporal fossa

Other options:

Aquino sign is the blanching of the tumour mass in a glomus tumour when the ipsilateral carotid artery is compressed manually.

Hanging drop/tear-drop sign is characteristic of an orbital "blow-out" fracture, which represents the orbital contents herniating through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum.

Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus - Antral sign or Holman Miller sign

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of his peripheral blood smear are given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum.

Plasmodium falciparum causes malignant tertian malaria. This means that the fever has a periodicity of 48 hours corresponding to one cycle of erythrocytic schizogony. Malignant because it is a more severe and fatal type of malaria.

Major manifestations of severe falciparum malaria include unarousable coma/ cerebral malaria (failure to localize or respond appropriately to stimuli or coma persisting for >30 min after generalized convulsion), acidosis, severe normocytic normochromic anemia, renal failure, pulmonary edema, hypoglycemia, shock, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Other manifestations include hemoglobinuria, hyperparasitemia, jaundice, and extreme weakness.

Falciparum malaria shows a very high percentage of RBCs containing ring forms. This high-level parasitemia is more often seen in Plasmodium falciparum infection than in infection by other plasmodia. After the ring form in the peripheral blood, the rest of the erythrocytic cycle occurs in the capillaries of the brain and internal organs. So, only ring forms can be seen in the peripheral blood and not the late trophozoites and schizonts. The gametocytes of P. falciparum are crescent-shaped or “banana-shaped” (as shown below), whereas those of the other plasmodia are spherical.

The treatment of choice is artesunate given at a dose of 2.4 mg/kg stat IV, followed by 2.4 mg/kg at 12 and 24 hours, and then daily if necessary.

In Plasmodium falciparum, recrudescence can be seen which is defined as the recurrence of asexual parasitemia. It usually occurs within 8 weeks of treatment and is due to incomplete treatment or drug resistance.

Related Pearl: Difference between plasmodium species

Stages found in peripheral blood Trophozoite, schizonts, gametocytes As in vivax Ring form, accole form, gametocytes Band forms
Infected erythrocyte Enlarged pale with Schuffner’s dots Pear-shaped, fimbriated, Jame’s dots Normal size, Maurer’s cleft Normal size, Ziemann’s stippling
Gametocyte Spherical, fills the cell Similar to but smaller than vivax Crescent, Banana shaped Similar to but smaller than vivax
Color of pigment Yellowish-brown Yellowish-brown Black Dark brown
