questions.text: Which of the following processes does not occur in muscles?
questions.solution:
Ketogenesis occurs in the liver and not in the muscles. Muscles can use ketone bodies for energy, especially during prolonged fasting or intense exercise, but they do not produce them.

Ketogenesis occurs primarily in the mitochondria of liver cells. Fatty acids are brought into the mitochondria via carnitine palmitoyltransferase (CPT-1) and then broken down into acetyl CoA via beta-oxidation. Two acetyl-CoA molecules are converted into acetoacetyl-CoA via the enzyme thiolase; this is also known as acetyl coenzyme A acetyltransferase (ACAT). Acetoacetyl-CoA is converted to HMG-CoA via the enzyme HMG-CoA synthase. HMG-CoA lyase then converts HMG-CoA to acetoacetate. Acetoacetate can be converted to either acetone through non-enzymatic decarboxylation or to beta-hydroxybutyrate via beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase.

Other options :

Option A: Glycogenolysis is the breakdown of glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, which can then be converted to glucose-6-phosphate and enter glycolysis for energy production.

Option C: Glycogenesis is the synthesis of glycogen from glucose molecules, allowing for the storage of glucose as glycogen for future energy needs.

Option D: Lipolysis is the breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol, which can be utilized for energy production through fatty acid oxidation.

Related Pearl: Ketogenesis

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is undergoing pubertal changes. Her tanner stage is stage 4 for breast development and pubic hair scale. Which of the following pubertal changes is not due to estrogen?
questions.solution:
Pubarche or development of axillary and pubic hair is not due to estrogen. It is due to testosterone (in both the sexes).

Puberty in females :

  • Involves the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche), breast development (thelarche), and an increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche).
  • Estradiol induces the development of secondary sex characteristics, including the breasts and reproductive tract, and increased fat in the hips.
  • Estrogens also regulate the growth spurt at puberty, vaginal cornification and cervical mucus production, induce closure of the epiphyses, have a positive effect in maintaining bone formation, and can antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone on bone.

In young girls before puberty the vaginal epithelium is thin and comprised of only basal and parabasal layers. During the reproductive years, the vaginal epithelium thickens and develops a distinct cornified layer due to the influence of estrogen. Cervical mucous production and menstruation are also changes occuring under the influence of estrogen and also progesterone.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and tiredness. There is no history of reactive airway disease or heart diseases previously. She has a history of breast cancer for which breast conservation surgery and chemoradiation were done. On examination, there were engorged neck veins and JVP showed rapid x and y descent and Chest Xray is as below.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the JVP findings of rapid X and Y descent  are suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis:

  • It is the condition where a thickened, fibrotic, and often calcified pericardium restricts the diastolic filling of the heart.
  • In developing countries, infectious etiologies like tuberculosis or viral infections are the most common cause of this condition.
  • Cardiac surgery and radiation therapy are also common causes.
  • Other causes include connective tissue disease, uremia, neoplasm, or idiopathic.
  • Clinically the patients present with dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue.
  • JVP findings - There is a rapid 'x' and 'y' descent. The rapid 'y' descent is more prominent and reflects rapid early ventricular diastolic filling. This occurs due to the constricting pericardium, increasing the atrial pressures.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis is difficult and is confirmed by multiple investigations
  • Hallmark findings of pericardial constriction are pericardial thickening, calcification, and abnormal ventricular diastolic function.
  • The X-ray can be normal or there may be non-specific cardiac enlargement, calcification, and roughened cardiac outline.
  • Echo can assess the hemodynamic function but it is accurate in identifying pericardial thickening.
  • CT and MRI are more sensitive investigations.
  • CT has an edge over MRI as it can detect calcification associated with this condition.
  • Pericardial thickness of > 4mm along with clinical features of constriction is highly suggestive of this diagnosis.
  • Cardiac MR may show diastolic septal bounce.
  • Hepatomegaly and ascites can be seen associated with this condition.

Constrictive pericarditis will have prominent y descent, prominent x descent, and Kussmaul's sign. Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Kussmaul’s sign is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration.

Other important conditions and their JVP tracings are

  • In Cardiac tamponade, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing of the patient will have a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.
  • Atrioventricular block will have cannon a waves
  • Atrial fibrillation will have absent a wave
  • Tricuspid regurgitation will have accentuated v wave with rapid y descent
  • Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A child presents with the complaint of perianal itching which occurs predominantly at night and disturbs sleep. Eggs of the causative organism have been shown in the following image. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus).

Enterobius vermicularis completes its entire life cycle in the human host. They are oviparous. Man acquires infection by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva through contaminated fingers and by autoinfection. 

At night, the gravid female worm comes out through the anus and lays its sticky eggs on the perianal skin. This leads to pruritus and the patient scratches the affected perianal area. The worm can crawl into the vulva and vagina causing irritation and a mucoid discharge. It can also cause chronic salpingitis, cervicitis, peritonitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and appendicitis.

Since pinworms are rarely released in faeces, stool examination is not useful in the diagnosis. The NIH swab (National Institutes of Health, USA) consists of a glass rod with a piece of transparent cellophane attached at one end with a rubber band. The cellophane part is used for swabbing by rolling over the perianal area. The cellophane piece is spread over a glass side and examined microscopically.

Plano-convex eggs containing a tadpole-shaped embryo, are deposited by the gravid female worm on perianal skin which causes pruritis.

Frequent hand washing, fingernail cleaning, regular bathing, and frequent washing of night clothes, and bed linen should be done. Treatment is with albendazole 400mg or mebendazole 100mg

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as 'C' in the below image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image as 'C' is Lentiform nucleus which is made up of Globus pallidus and Putamen.

Nomenclature of basal ganglia:

  • Corpus striatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen+ globus pallidus
  • Lentiform nucleus: Putamen + globus pallidus
  • Neostriatum: Caudate nucleus + putamen

Other options:

A - Caudate nucleus

B - Insula (portion of cerebral cortex folded deep within the floor of lateral sulcus, associated with cardiac arrhythmias)

D - Third ventricle

questions.text: In the cardiac muscle, the inhibition of Na+K+ATPase results in __?
questions.solution:
The inhibition of Na+K+-ATPase results in depolarisation.

An energy (ATP)-dependent pump system (Na+/K+-ATPase), is located on the sarcolemma, which pumps Na+ out and K+ into the cell.The Na+/K+-ATPase pump is electrogenic because it extrudes three Na+ for every two K+ entering the cell. By pumping more positive charges out of the cell than into it, the pump creates a negative potential within the cell. This electrogenic potential may be up to −10 mV.

If this pump stops working (such as when ATP is lost under hypoxic conditions), or if the activity of the pump is inhibited by cardiac glycosides such as digoxin, Na+ accumulates within the cell and intracellular K+ falls,resulting in a less negative (more depolarized) resting membrane potential.

Inhibition of this pump, therefore, causes depolarization resulting from changes in Na+ and K+ concentration gradients and from the loss of an electrogenic component of the membrane potential.

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: The stain used for identifying Cryptococcus is _____
questions.solution:
The stain used for identifying Cryptococcus is India ink stain.

Indian ink is a negative staining method that provides a uniformly coloured background. The unstained organisms stand out in contrast to the background. It is useful in the demonstration of organisms with capsules that do not take simple stains. It is also used to stain slender bacteria like spirochetes.

The India ink preparation is employed to detect the presence of Cryptococcus neoformans. It is seen as a globular, encapsulated yeast cell with or without budding, between 5 to 20 μm in diameter in size. Cryptococcus has a polysaccharide capsule which is seen against a black background.

Cryptococcus can be cultured from biologic samples like the CSF, sputum, and skin biopsy on routine fungal and bacterial culture media. Colonies are opaque, white-to-cream coloured, and may turn orange-tan or brown after prolonged incubation. They have a mucoid appearance due to the presence of the capsule around the yeast cells.

The image below shows the fungus Cryptococcus, stained with Indian ink.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains These include Eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, Congo red, etc. and are mostly used to stain pathological specimens.
Basic stains.

1.    Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in counterstaining in quellung reaction of streptococcus pneumoniae.  

2.    Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction of anthrax bacilli
Neutral stains

1.    Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

2.    Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and some other spirochete and protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contains more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: Used to distinguish cells by cell-wall type. To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain: Used to distinguish acid-fast bacteria from non-acid-fast cells. Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid – fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Used for rapid scanning of the smear, where the AFB appear fluorescent green against a black background Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "Chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (Anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–Starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor White Staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain Calcofluor white, which greatly enhances visibility of fungal element in tissue or other specimens. It is especially useful for the identification of Mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.   It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For Cell wall demonstration

questions.text: According to the law, nothing is an offence if a person is of an unsound mind and is not able to understand that the nature and consequences of his/her act are wrong. Which rule of insanity applies in this case?
questions.solution:
Mc Naughten’s rule is the correct answer. Mc Naughten’s rule states “Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who at the time of doing it by reason of unsoundness of mind is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law”.

  • The rules are:
    • McNaughten's rule states that every man is to be presumed to be sane, and possesses a sufficient degree of reason to be responsible for his crimes until the contrary is proved.
    • To establish an insanity defense, it must be clearly proved that, at the time of the committing of the act, the accused was laboring under ‘such a defect of reason, from a disease of the mind, as not to know the nature and quality of the act he was doing; or if he did know it, that he did not know he was doing what was wrong’.

Other options:

Options A and C: Durham's rule and Curren's rule are the other tests for insanity.

Durhams's rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

Curren’s rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.

Option D: Irresistible impulse test- This rule is similar to Curren's rule. 

Related Pearl: IPC Sec 84, McNaughten's rule

McNaughten's rule, Section 84 IPC:  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

It states that an accused is not criminally responsible if he was suffering from:

  • Defect of reason and unsoundness of mind: the law recognizes only those diseases which impair the thinking abilities of the mind. So, not all medically insane people are legally insane, as emotional disturbances that affect the mind are not considered if they do not directly affect cognition.
  • That he did not know the nature and the quality of the act he is doing:  the law needs the unsoundness of mind to exist at the time of the act to such a degree that the person is not aware of what he is doing and whether it is right or wrong to do. Absence of a motive or forethought is also considered as a criteria for determining unsoundness of mind.

McNaughten’s rule now comes under Section 22 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was prescribed a diuretic by a doctor for the management of hypertension. Which of the following diuretic acts on the site 'A' marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The site 'A' in the given image represents a distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide, thiazide type of diuretuic act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). 

They block the Na+/Cl- symport in the DCT leading to an increase in Na+ and Cl− excretion. Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension. They are also used for the treatment of edema associated with congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, chronic renal failure, and acute glomerulonephritis.

The advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost

The adverse effects include extracellular volume depletion, hypotension, hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis, hypomagnesemia, hypercalcemia, and hyperuricemia.

Other options:

Option A: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits Na+-K+-2Cl– symport. They are used in acute pulmonary edema, edema associated with congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, and nephrotic syndrome.

Option C: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and primarily acts in the proximal tubule. It is used in glaucoma, altitude sickness, diuretic resistance, and metabolic alkalosis.

Option D: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that acts primarily in the loop of Henle. It also acts in the proximal tubule. It is used in elevated intraocular pressure and elevated intracranial pressure.

Related Pearl: Effect of diuretics on excretion of electrolytes

Diuretics Sodium Potassium Calcium

Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑
Loop diuretics ↑↑ ↑↑ ↑↑
Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓
Epithelial sodium channel blockers ↑ ↓ ↓
Aldosterone antagonists ↑ ↓ Insufficient data

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about thoracolumbar fascia?

choices.text: In the lumbar region it is in 4 layers
In the thoraic region it is attatched medially to the vertebrae
The posterior and middle layers join with the anterior layer to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis

questions.solution:
In the lumbar region, the fascia consists of 3 layers - anterior, middle and posterior.

The thoracolumbar fascia is a complex arrangement of multiple fascial layers in the thoracolumbar region. This fascia encloses the paraspinal, quadratus lumborum, and lattismus dorsi muscles.

a) Thoraic region: The thoracolumbar fascia provides a thin fibrous covering for the extensor muscles of the vertebral column.

Relations:

  • Medially attached to the spines of the thoracic vertebrae
  • Laterally to the angles of the ribs

b)Lumbar region: It is in three layers:

  • Anterior
    • Medially - anterior surface of the lumbar transverse processes.
    • Laterally - blends with the middle layer at the lateral border of the quadratus lumborum.
    • Superiorly - lateral arcuate ligament and tip of Transverse process L1 to 12th rib.
    • Inferiorly - inner lip of iliac crest and the ilio-lumbar ligament.
  • Middle
    • Medially - tips of the lumbar transverse processes and inter-transverse ligaments.
    • Laterally - blends with the anterior layer at the lateral border of the quadratus lumborum.
    • Superiorly - lower border of the 12th rib and lumbocostal ligament.
    • Inferiorly - intermediate area of the iliac crest.
  • Posterior
    • Medially - lumbar and sacral spines and interspinous ligaments.
    • Laterally - blends with the middle layer at the lateral border of the erector spinae.
    • Superiorly - back of thorax - lumbar vertebral spines.
    • Inferiorly - outer lip of the iliac crest

The posterior and middle layers unite to form a tough raphe at the lateral margin of erector spinae, and at the lateral border of quadratus lumborum they are joined by the anterior layer to form the aponeurotic origin of transversus abdominis.

Function:

  • The attachments have a role in lifting and load transfer ,although controversial.
  • They contain nociceptive nerve endings that may be responsible for back pain due to injury to the area and also impaired proprioceptive signalling.

questions.text: What is the embryological basis of the developmental defect shown in the image below?

choices.text: Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of posterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of complete neural tube
Failure in closure of caudal neuropore of neural tube

questions.solution:
The image shows anencephaly.

Failure of the anterior end (cranial end) of the neural tube to close is known as exencephaly. As a result of this, the skull vault does not form. This leaves the malformed brain exposed. The exposed brain tissue degenerates, leaving a mass of necrotic tissue. This defect with the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is known as anencephaly. The brain stem remains intact.

In some cases, the closure defect of the neural tube extends caudally, and the spinal cord is affected. This condition is known as craniorachischisis, where there is anencephaly plus a large defect involving the spine. 

Neurulation refers to the formation of the neural tube from the neural plate. The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system. 

Steps of neurulation

  • The notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to thicken and form the neural plate.
  • The neural plate lengthens and the lateral edges elevate to form the neural folds, and the mid-region gets depressed to form the neural groove.
  • The neural folds approach each and fuse in the midline in a craniocaudal direction to form a tube-like structure called the neural tube.
  • The anterior opening of the neural tube (cranial neuropore) closes by day 25 and the posterior opening (caudal neuropore) closes by day 28.
  • The neural tube becomes the central nervous system.

questions.text: In a triage system, highest priority and dead patients are respectively colour coded by
questions.solution:
Highest priority patients are coded red and dead patients are coded black.

  • Triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of the severity of their injuries and the likelihood of their survival with prompt medical intervention.
  • Triage is the only approach that can provide maximum benefit to the greatest number of injured in a major disaster situation.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Priority Type of patients
Red High Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer (Eg. massive hemorrhage, tension pneumothorax)
Yellow Medium Possible resuscitation or surgery in next 24 hours (Eg. Isolated simple fracture)
Green Low Ambulatory patients or minor illness (Eg. Isolated abrasions, contusions, sprains)
Black Least  Dead or moribund patients (Eg. massive head injuries, 95% third degree burns)

questions.text: A patient who presents to the OPD has a visual field defect as shown below. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma marked as 3 in the image given. 

Options marked in the image are:

1. Left optic nerve 
3. Otic chiasma
4. Left optic tract 
5. Left lateral geniculate nucleus

Hemianopia or hemianopsia refers to loss of sight in half the visual field. Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours. Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, and suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

Damage to the middle part of the optic chiasm affects fibres crossing at the nasal retina of each eye, leaving the uncrossed fibres from the temporal retinas intact. The resulting loss of vision is confined to the temporal visual field of each eye and this is known as bitemporal hemianopia. It is also called heteronymous hemianopia to emphasize the fact that the parts of the visual field that are lost in each eye do not overlap.

Individuals with this condition are able to see in both left and right central visual fields, with both eyes open. However, all information from the most peripheral parts of visual fields (which are seen only by the nasal retinas) is lost.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child was brought to your clinic with an erythematous rash on the cheek which later spread downwards to involve his trunk and limbs. He has also had a low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection for the past few days. The suspected organism contains single-stranded DNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are strongly suggestive of erythema infectiosum. It is caused by Parvoviruses. Parvovirus B19 is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus. 

Clinically, parvovirus B-19 infection may have several presentations-

  • Erythema infectiosum- Also known as the fifth disease. The incubation period after infection is typically around 4-14 days. The hallmark of erythema infectiosum is the characteristic rash, which appears initially as erythematous facial flushing, often described as a “slapped cheek” appearance. Later the rash spreads rapidly or concurrently to the trunk and proximal extremities as diffuse macular erythema. The child may be febrile. 
  • Transient aplastic crisis- It may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anaemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients with aplastic crisis appear ill with fever, malaise, and pale with tachycardia and tachypnea due to profound anaemia. The rash may or may not be present. Children with sickle-cell disease may also develop vaso-occlusive crises.
  • Pure red cell aplasia- Persistent B19V infection that results in pure red cell aplasia has been reported in a wide variety of immunosuppressed patients, including patients with congenital immunodeficiency, AIDS, and lymphoproliferative disorders and transplant recipients.
  • Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

It is a clinical diagnosis that usually does not require investigations. However, in the case of pregnant women or with other manifestations an IgM ELISA or PCR assay may be done.

It is self-limited and resolves on its own.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a six-month history of recurrent, large-volume, watery diarrhea. She reports experiencing multiple episodes per day, often waking her at night. She has also noted significant weight loss and episodes of muscle weakness. Laboratory findings reveal hypokalemia. Imaging studies of the abdomen show a mass in the tail of the pancreas. Which pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent, large-volume, watery diarrhea with laboratory evidence of hypokalemia and a mass in the pancreatic tail is most likely afflicted by a VIPoma.

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumours (VIPomas) are  pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours that secrete excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptides (VIP) which are responsible for the secretory watery diarrhoea and other symptoms. The patient commonly presents with severe intermittent watery diarrhoea leading to dehydration, and weakness from fluid and electrolyte losses.

Electrolyte abnormalities in VIPoma include:

  • Metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia- due to a large amount of GI loss and bicarbonate wasting
  • Hypochlorhydria- due to the direct gastric acid inhibitory effect of VIP
  • Hypomagnesemia- due to severe diarrhoea
  • Hyperglycemia- due to the increased glycogenolytic activity of VIP
  • Hypercalcemia- due to dehydration, coincidental MEN1 syndrome, or secretion by the tumor of a calcitrophic peptide

Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumor (VIPoma) is also referred to as Verner–Morrison syndrome/ WDHA syndrome:

WDHA stands for:

  • WD - Watery Diarrhea
  • H – Hypokalemia
  • A – Achlorhydria

Metastases commonly occurs in the liver, lymph nodes, bones, and kidney.

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level (upto 250 to 500 pg/ml) and a history of large-volume diarrhea (> 5L/day). A CT scan localizes most VIPomas. EUS is the most sensitive imaging method.

While suspecting a case of VIPoma it is essential to conduct a VIP assay so as to confirm the presence of other tumors of neural crest origin such as neuroblastoma or pheochromocytoma. 

The medical management of VIPoma:

  • Initial medical management is symptomatic with correction of fluids and electrolyte imbalance. 
  • Somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide inhibit secretion of VIP and are used for symptomatic control.
  • Glucocorticoids are used in patients refractory to somatostatin analogs.
  • Interferon-alpha has also been used in patients in patients not responding to the above medications.

The surgical management of VIPoma:

  • Complete resection is the treatment of choice for primary tumors and is usually a distal pancreatectomy. If the tumor cannot be excised completely, surgical debulkingmay be done 
  • Radiofrequency ablation and cryoablation
  • Hepatic artery embolization is a palliative treatment measure in patients with unresectable hepatic metastases.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Syndrome

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms
  • Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.
  • In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngeal cancer stage T1b N0 M0?

choices.text: Both vocal cords involved and fixed
Both vocal cords involved and mobile
One vocal cord involved and fixed
One vocal cord involved and mobile

questions.solution:
In stage T1b N0 M0 laryngeal cancer, both the vocal cords are involved and are mobile.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen revealed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a whitish pupillary reflex and Flexner-Winterstein rosettes on histopathological examination has retinoblastoma. Flexner Winterstein rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It belongs to small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision. Image below showing leukocoria of left eye

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumour include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of Vincristine, Carboplatin, and Etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
Enucleation is done when
  • The tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • The optic nerve is involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

Other options:

Option B - Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement.

Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes. They express neuronal markers such as synaptophysin.

Option C - Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. The child usually presents with rapidly progressive unilateral proptosis. There are 4 subtypes - embryonal, alveolar, botyroid, and pleomorphic. Cells show light microscopic features of striated muscle differentiation. Immunohistochemistry is positive for desmin.

Option D - Astrocytoma of the retina and optic nerve head is rare. It is usually asymptomatic and is most frequently seen in tuberous sclerosis. Fundus examination reveals a yellowish or white plaque, nodule, or mulberry-like lesion. These lesions are semitransparent peripherally and calcified centrally.

Image showing calcified astrocytoma:

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell into a manhole and injured his perineum. He was unable to pass urine and blood was seen at the tip of the urethra. A diagnosis of bulbar urethral injury was made.  Where do you least expect the urine to get collected in this case?
questions.solution:
In bulbar urethral injury, the medial portion of the thigh is the least likely site for the collection of urine.

The rupture of the urethra below the urogenital diaphragm will result in extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal pouch, penis and scrotum in males and labia majora in females, and the anterior abdominal wall.

The superficial fascia of the abdomen is divided below the umbilicus into a superficial fatty layer (fascia of Camper) and a deep membranous layer (fascia of Scarpa). Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the membranous layer of the superficial perineal fascia (Colles' fascia). 

Colles' fascia is attached to fascia lata (the deep fascia of the thigh) along the Holden's line that extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. Extravasated fluid cannot pass into the medial thigh below Holden's line due to the firm attachment of Colles' fascia to the fascia lata.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who was on a diet consisting predominantly of packaged and reheated meals presents with iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations. Which of the following antioxidant deficiency can lead to these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Diet deficient in vitamin C or ascorbic acid, can lead to microcytic-hypochromic anemia, defective collagen synthesis, and bleeding manifestations.

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. Ascorbic acid cannot be synthesized in human beings because of the absence of L-gulonolactone oxidase. Gooseberries and citrus fruits are rich sources of vitamin C. 

It is mainly required for hydroxylation reactions. It also maintains vitamin E and many metal cofactors (eg. copper) in a reduced state. The active form of vitamin C is ascorbic acid.

Iron absorption is enhanced by vitamin C. It reduces the ferric iron to its ferrous form, thereby helping in the process of absorption of dietary iron from the intestine.

Vitamin C deficiency causes

  • Decreased hydroxylation of proline and lysine, which results in defective collagen synthesis and bleeding manifestations.
  • Decreased absorption of iron leading to microcytic-hypochromic anemia

A deficiency state of vitamin C results in scurvy. Clinical features are:

  • Loose and spongy gums along with loose teeth
  • Swollen joints
  • Hemorrhages
  • Bleeding into the skin - ecchymosis, purpura, petechiae
  • Bone changes
  • Microcytic anemia (due to decreased absorption of iron from the intestine)
  • Scorbutic rosary - sharp, tender beading at the costochondral junctions.

Other options:

Option A- Glutathione is present in glutathione peroxidase. This enzyme acts as an antioxidant. It helps in the destruction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides.

Option B- β-carotene is provitamin A, found in plants. It helps in the formation of retinaldehyde which is utilized in vision, and retinoic acid which plays a role in the control of gene expression.

Option D- Zinc is an essential component of several metalloenzymes like carboxypeptidases, carbonic anhydrase II, adenosine deaminase, the cytosolic form of superoxide dismutase, etc. Chronic zinc deficiency can cause dwarfism, hypogonadism, dermatitis, and T-cell immunodeficiency. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by abnormalities in zinc absorption.

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

questions.text: A 32-year-old traveler was lost in the desert. He was found after 2 days. He says that he has not consumed food or water for more than 24 hours. His vitals were normal. Which of the following part of the kidney must have been the site of maximum water reabsorption in this case?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule is the site of maximum water reabsorption about 67% of the filtered water.

The driving force for water reabsorption is a transtubular osmotic gradient established by reabsorption of solutes.

Based on the ultrastructure proximal tubule is divided into three segments:

  • S1 segment: 1st half of PCT
  • S2 segment: 2nd half of PCT and 1st half of proximal straight tubule
  • S3 segment: 2nd half of proximal straight tubule

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

questions.text: Which of the following indicators is the best to know the overall burden of disease?
questions.solution:
DALY is the best measure of the overall disease burden in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

DALY (Disability Adjusted Life Years):

  • It can measure both mortality and disability together.
  • One DALY can be considered a lost year of a "healthy" life.
  • The sum of these DALYs across the population, or the burden of disease, can be thought of as a measurement of the gap between current health status and an ideal health situation where the entire population lives to an advanced age, free of disease and disability.

DALYs for a disease or health condition are calculated as the sum of the Years of Life Lost (YLL) due to premature mortality in the population and the Years Lost due to Disability (YLD) for people living with the health condition or its consequences:

Calculation

DALY = YLL + YLD

The YLL basically corresponds to the number of deaths multiplied by the standard life expectancy at the age at which death occurs. The basic formula for YLL (without yet including other social preferences discussed below), is the following for a given cause, age, and sex:

YLL = N x L

where:

  • N = number of deaths
  • L = standard life expectancy at the age of death in years

Prevalence YLD

YLD = P x DW

where:

  • P = number of prevalent cases
  • DW = disability weight

Other options:

Option A: QALY is a disability rate indicator. It is based on the number of years that would be added to life due to medical intervention. A utility value of 1.0 is given for each year of perfect health and 0 for death. It is the measure of the disease burden which includes both quality and quantity of life.

Option B: HALE (health adjusted life expectancy) is an indicator that estimates the number of years a newborn is expected to live in full health based on the current rates of ill health and mortality. HALE is calculated using the life expectancy at birth with an adjustment for time spent in poor health. It was known as DALE (disability-adjusted life expectancy) previously.

Option D: DFLE (disability-free life expectancy) is an indicator that estimates the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability if the current pattern of mortality and disability continues to apply. It is also known as active life expectancy and is calculated by:

DFLE = Life expectancy - Duration of disability

Related Pearl: QALY vs. DALY

QALY and DALY are disability indicators used as measures of health in a population.

QALY

Quality Adjusted Life Years

DALY

Disability Adjusted Life Years

 

Measures quality of life in health gain

 

Measures health loss in quality of life

 

Indicator of cost effectiveness of intervention

 

Indicator of overall burden of disease in a population

 

Expressed as 1 or 0 where,

1 = Perfect health

0 = Death

 

 

Expressed as 0 or 1 where,

0 = Perfect health

1 = Death

questions.text: Adam's apple is made up of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Adam's apple of formed from the thyroid cartilage.

The thyroid angle measures 90 degrees (right-angled) in men.

It is the angle between the two thyroid lamina in the midline. It depends on gender:

  • Men: 90 degrees (forms the prominent adam’s apple)
  • Women: 120 degrees.

The thyroid cartilage is the largest cartilage in the larynx, which is also known as the voice box. It is located in the front of the neck and forms the prominence known as the Adam's apple in males. The Adam's apple is more prominent in males due to the larger size of the thyroid cartilage in comparison to females.

Other options:

The cricoid cartilage, on the other hand, is another cartilage in the larynx located just below the thyroid cartilage. It is a complete ring-shaped structure and provides structural support to the larynx.

The hyoid cartilage is a U-shaped bone located in the neck, above the thyroid cartilage. It does not directly contribute to the formation of the Adam's apple.

The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped cartilage located at the base of the tongue, which acts as a lid to cover the entrance to the larynx during swallowing, preventing food and liquid from entering the airway.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man after his retirement party came with the complaint of sudden painless loss of vision in his left eye for the past 2 hours. Fundoscopic examination shows a similar picture given below. What is the most probable cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given fundoscopic image shows a cherry-red spot, which is a feature of CRAO.

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Risk factors include

  • Heart disease
  • Carotid artery disease
  • Mucormycosis
  • Varicella infection
  • Radiation exposure
  • Trauma

Etiology:

  • Emboli - emboli having carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. Other emboli are - cholesterol emboli, calcium emboli, and platelet fibrin emboli
  • Atherosclerosis-related thrombosis
  • Retinal arteritis with obliteration
  • Angiospasm
  • Raised intraocular pressure
  • Thrombophilic disorders

Clinical features are

  • Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Severe oedema- the whole retina looks white in colour
  • Cherry red spots
  • Marked attenuation of arteries – thread-like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein – cattle track appearance

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photo disruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: Identify the image.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts lepromatous leprosy in the infiltrated stage of the disease.

In lepromatous leprosy, the earliest clinical manifestations are dermal. 

The early features include: 

  • Numerous, ill-defined, shiny macules
  • Anhidrosis
  • Normal sensation
  • Nasal symptoms - stuffiness, discharge, epistaxis
  • Peripheral oedema due to capillary stasis

Early nerve involvement is asymptomatic. Peripheral nerves are affected first. In the late stages, even facial and corneal nerves can be involved. Loss of sensation begins as patchy and later becomes extensive. Stocking and glove anesthesia is a late manifestation. The affected skin can become dry and ichthyotic.

The late stage of lepromatous leprosy gives rise to the following features:

  • Leonine facies - infiltration of skin folds
  • Madarosis - loss of eyelashes eyebrow hair
  • Rat-bitten ear - repeated ulceration and healing
  • Saddle nose deformity - breakdown of nasal cartilage

Lepromatous leprosy develops in three stages:

  1. Early macular stage
  2. Infiltrated stage - induration due to dermal infiltration, marked in face and ear lobe
  3. Late nodulo-plaque stage - progress to papules, nodules, and plaques, which ulcerate.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows an HIV virus.

The human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is a spherical, enveloped RNA virus. The nucleocapsid has an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core, enclosing the ribonucleoproteins. The genome comprises two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

The viral core is surrounded by a matrix protein called p17, which lies underneath the virion envelope. It contains

  1. Major capsid protein p24
  2. Nucleocapsid protein p7/p9 
  3. Two copies of viral genomic RNA
  4. Three viral enzymes (protease, reverse transcriptase, and integrase).

The viral envelope is studded by two viral glycoproteins, gp120 and gp41, which are critical for HIV infection of cells.

Other options:

The structure of CMV is shown below

 

The structure of EBV is shown below

 

The structure of coronavirus is shown below

questions.text: In rural areas, one ASHA worker is assigned to a population of ___ people.
questions.solution:
In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA.

An Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) does not procure ORS, contraceptives, IFA tablets, etc. from the CHC for her community.

An ASHA acts as a depot holder for these essential supplies, hence making them readily available to her community. These include Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORS), Iron Folic Acid tablets (IFA), chloroquine, Disposable Delivery Kits (DDK), Oral Pills & Condoms, etc.

General norm:

  • Must be a woman - married/divorced/widow (age group 25-45 years)
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000.

Relaxations in the general norm:

  • If no candidate is available with a qualification of 10th standard, the requirement can be relaxed to 8th standard.
  • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Note: The States have been given the flexibility to relax the population norms as well as the educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions as far as her recruitment is concerned. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the conversion of T4 to T3, in the peripheral tissue?
questions.solution:
Peripheral T3 conversion from T4 is catalyzed by the enzyme iodothryronine deiodinase I. T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone. It is expressed predominantly in the peripheral tissues. 

Iodothyronine deiodinase II: Iodothyronine deiodinase type II (DIO2) is an enzyme responsible for the activation of T4 to T3 in certain specific tissues, such as the hypothalamus and pituitary gland.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with an acute painful red-eye. An image of her eye is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and a red eye showing corneal edema and a mid-dilated and vertically oval pupil are suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. The pupil is non-reactive to both light and accommodation.

Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma refers to the occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris (iridotrabecular contact [ITC]), obstructing aqueous outflow. It can be primary when it occurs in an anatomically predisposed eye or secondary to another ocular or systemic factor.

Acute angle-closure glaucoma is an ocular emergency that causes acute red-eye and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms:

  • Acute onset ocular pain with nausea or vomiting
  • Intermittent blurring of vision with halos
  • Photophobia or
  • Loss of vision.

It is also associated with at least three of the following signs:

  • Ciliary congestion
  • Corneal edema and subsequent haziness
  • Fixed and mid-dilated, usually oval pupil
  • Shallow anterior chamber
  • Intraocular pressure elevated above 40 mmHg.

Immediate medical management mainly aims at lowering IOP using drugs such as oral acetazolamide or intravenous mannitol. The definitive treatment is laser peripheral iridotomy. This must be followed by prophylaxis of the fellow eye, long-term glaucoma surveillance and management of intraocular pressure in both eyes.

questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The image representing a clinical test where the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly is Cottle’s test 

This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side.

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV.

 

Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Option D: Trotter’s method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. He should pinch the nose firmly for 5 to 10 mins and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic presented with severe pain in ear and otorrhoea not responding to antibiotics. On examination, granulation tissue is seen in EAC, facial nerve palsy was present. The likely diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
Elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhoea, and granulation tissue in EAC and facial nerve palsy indicates malignant otitis externa.

It is termed malignant, though being an infection due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa:

  • Pseudomonas infection in the elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of EAC.
  • Facial paralysis is common.
  • Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease. Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient

The treatment of malignant otitis external would include control of diabetes, ear toileting to remove the discharge, debris or granulation tissue, antibiotic therapy against Pseudomonas with fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins, beta-lactam antibiotics with/without aminoglycosides.

If the patient is not responsive, culture and sensitivity of ear discharge should be done.

questions.text: A patient presented with midline swelling in the neck. Biopsy revealing orphan Annie's eye nuclei as shown in the image below is suggestive of ________:
questions.solution:
The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma:

  • The carcinoma shows branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk covered with simple or stratified cuboidal epithelium.
  • At high power, the nuclei appear optically clear or empty as the chromatin is dispersed. These empty appearing nuclei are called Orphan Annie eye nuclei.
  • Concentric calcified structures called psammoma bodies are usually seen.
  • Foci of lymphatic invasion by the tumor are usually present.

Note : 

The presence of Orphan Annie-eye nuclei is diagnostic of papillary thyroid cancer, regardless of the presence of papillary architecture.

The image below shows papillary thyroid carcinoma with characteristic Orphan Annie eye nuclei:

The image below shows psammoma bodies in papillary thyroid cancer.

questions.text: The culture media that is used to differentiate lactose fermenters and non-lactose fermenters is______
questions.solution:
MacConkey agar is used to distinguish lactose fermenters (pink) from non-lactose fermenters (colourless or pale). It is a selective and differential media.

It is selective because bile salts and dyes inhibit gram-positive organisms and gram-negative cocci. It is differential because the pH indicator turns pink-red when the lactose is fermented.

Contents of MacConkey agar: Mnemonic: PLANT

  • Peptone 
  • Lactose                 
  • Agar
  • Neutral red
  • Sodium Taurocholate

Lactose-fermenting organisms (Eg: E. coli) produce a pink colour, and non-lactose-fermenting organisms (Shigella sp., Salmonella sp.) do not change the colour as shown below. 

Other options:

Option B: Alkaline bile salt agar (BSA) at pH 8.2 is a simple medium used for the culture of Vibrio cholerae. The colonies are similar to those on nutrient agar.

Option C: Thayer–Martin agar is used for Nesseria.

Option D: Sabouraud Dextrose agar is used for fungal culture.

questions.text: A chronic asthmatic patient who is on inhaled steroids presents with a history of a burning sensation on eating hot or spicy food and the following findings are seen. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of oral steroid use along with a lesion on the tongue points towards a diagnosis of candida infection.

Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis appears as a red, raw-looking lesion. It may or may not be related to pseudo membranes. On the tongue, there is a loss of the lingual papillae, leaving a smooth area. It can occur after long-term corticosteroids or antibiotics usage or those with HIV. Other names for this condition include acute atrophic oral candidiasis and antibiotic sore tongue.

Cutaneous and mucosal infections manifest as thrush affecting the tongue, lips, gums, and palate. It is seen as a patchy to confluent whitish pseudomembranous lesion and is commonly associated with AIDS. Candida may also invade the vaginal mucosa leading to vulvovaginitis, and the nails, and around the nail plate leading to onychomycosis. Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

Other options:

Burning mouth syndrome (BMS) is a burning sensation in the mouth with no underlying dental or medical cause where no related signs of disease are found in the mouth.

Migratory glossitis / geographic tongue is due to the rapid loss and regrowth of filiform papillae of the tongue. It is a benign inflammatory condition of the tongue associated with psoriasis and reactive arthritis. Geographic tongue, though consistent with the clinical image is not the best fit considering the clinical history. It is usually asymptomatic but can be occasionally associated with a sore tongue.

Oral lichen planus is associated with Wickham striae in the oral cavity. They are fine white lines in a lacy or fern-like pattern that cross the plaques in lichen planus.

questions.text: Which test uses the graph given below to assess the viral load in a test sample ?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Ct value(Cycle threshold) of Real-time RTPCR which can be used to assess the viral genetic load.  

The image shows a graph with cycle number on the X-axis and relative fluorescence on the Y-axis. At 25.6 there is an exponential rise in the fluorescence which is the Ct value for the sample.

The cycle threshold (Ct) can be defined as the thermal cycle number at which the fluorescent signal exceeds that of the background and thus passes the threshold for positivity.

The first step for a real-time RTPCR is by extracting the viral RNA from the sample followed by purifying and concentrating it. They are then added to a mixture of primers, nucleotide bases, enzymes for the reaction, and fluorescently labeled probes (short stretches of nucleic acid which stick to the target ). The primers initially attach to the viral nucleic acid which is RNA and a complementary DNA strand is made using the nucleotides in the mixture. It is then subjected to repeated thermal cycles so that the copies of the viral targets are increased. The labeled probes stick to the viral genome and emit a fluorescent signal. An exponential rise occurs early when the viral load in the sample is high when compared to a less viral load.

A typical RT-PCR assay will have a maximum of 40 thermal cycles. The lower the Ct value the higher the quantity of viral genetic material in the sample.

A 3-point increase in Ct value is roughly equivalent to a 10-fold decrease in the quantity of viral genetic material. Low Ct values more likely indicate acute disease and high infectivity whereas high Ct values can be attributed to reduced viral load but might need clinical interpretation.

Note:

Ct values cannot be used to compare different types of assays nor does it provide information on the course of the illness. However, it can be used for clinical management in a hospital setting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old healthy man with a history of small streaks of blood in his stools is being sent for a colonoscopy to screen for colon cancer. This type of prevention is _______
questions.solution:
Colonoscopies for early detection/screening of colon cancer are an example of secondary prevention.

Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment are the components of secondary prevention. Some examples of secondary prevention are as follows:

  • Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer
  • Mammography, for early detection of breast cancer
  • Colonoscopies, for early detection of colon cancer
  • Blood Pressure Screening

Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as dysplasia in this case. These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention to correct departures from a state of health.

questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in infants?
questions.solution:
In infants, the spinal cord ends at the L3 level.

As the child grows, the spinal cord moves up with age. Thus in adults, the distal termination of the spinal cord is at the lower border of L1.

The nerve roots from the lower end of the spinal cord form the cauda equina which exit through the intervertebral foramina. These fibers float in the dural sac and tend to be pushed away when a needle is advanced as in spinal anesthesia.

Thus spinal anesthesia is administered in adults below the lower border of L1 and in children below the lower border of L3, to minimize the chances of injury to the spinal cord

questions.text: A 50-year-old male diagnosed with carcinoma of the larynx is scheduled for treatment and has undergone the procedure shown in the image below. At what level is the incision made for this procedure?

choices.text: At the level of the 2nd tracheal ring
At the level of the 1st tracheal ring

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a 50-year-old male with carcinoma of the larynx undergoing a tracheostomy, as shown in the image. The incision is made at the level of the first tracheal ring, above the isthmus, in a patient with laryngeal carcinoma, and this procedure is referred to as a high tracheostomy.

Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. High tracheostomy is performed above the level of the thyroid isthmus (the Isthmus lies against the II, III, and IV tracheal rings). The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx.

It provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
It uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood.

Indications of tracheostomy:

  • Respiratory obstruction due to infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria).
  • Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures.
  • Neoplasms.
  • Foreign bodies or edema.
  • Retained secretionsInability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles.
  • Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions.
  • Painful cough.
  • Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Steps of Tracheostomy:

  • Incision: Make a vertical incision in the midline from the cricoid cartilage to above the sternal notch. For a better cosmetic outcome for elective procedures, a 5 cm transverse incision two fingers' breadth above the sternal notch can be used.
  • Dissection: Dissect tissues in the midline. Displace or ligate any dilated veins encountered to control bleeding.
  • Muscle separation: Separate and retract the strap muscles of the neck laterally to expose underlying structures.
  • Thyroid isthmus management: Displace the thyroid isthmus upwards or divide and ligate it with sutures.
  • Local anaesthesia: Inject a few drops of 4% lignocaine into the trachea to suppress coughing.
  • Tracheal incision: Fix the trachea with a hook and make a vertical incision between the third and fourth tracheal rings(Option D), converting it into a circular opening. Avoid dividing the first tracheal ring to prevent perichondritis and stenosis.
  • Inserting the tube: Insert a tracheostomy tube of appropriate size into the tracheal opening and secure it with tapes.
  • Avoid tight suturing: Avoid tightly suturing or packing the skin incision to prevent subcutaneous emphysema.
  • Dressing: Place a gauze dressing between the skin and the flange of the tracheostomy tube around the stoma to absorb secretions, provide a barrier against infection, and allow air to escape, promoting proper healing.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: Cherry red post mortem lividity is seen in:
questions.solution:
Cherry red postmortem lividity is characteristic of Carbon monoxide poisoning.

Carbon monoxide poisoning:

  • Cherry red discoloration of the skin, mucosa, post-mortem lividity (hypostasis), blood, and viscera, etc.
  • If the blood is taken in a test tube and diluted with water and held against a light or white background, the pink color will be better appreciated.

Postmortem staining in poisonings:

                  Poisoning      Color of lividity
1. Carbon monoxide Cherry red
2. Cyanide Bright red
3. Phosphorous Dark brown
4. Opium  Black
5. Hydrogen sulphide Blue-green
6.Nitrate,Nitrite,Aniline Dark brown
7. Pottasium cyanide Deep blue
8. In clostridium perfringens infection Bronze
9. Hypothermia Bright pink

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is deficient in Von Gierke's disease?
questions.solution:
Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke's disease (Type I GSD).

These patients have hepatomegaly, fasting hypoglycemia, and hypotonia overlap. Further, in von Gierke's disease, there are increased serum lactate levels and hyperuricemia.

Other options:

Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency causes Her's disease (Type VI GSD). It results in the accumulation of glycogen in the liver causing hepatomegaly and mild hypoglycemia. Hypotonia is not seen.

Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency causes McArdle syndrome (Type V GSD) which presents with poor exercise tolerance, low lactate levels following exercise, and accumulation of glycogen in muscles.

Glycogen debranching enzyme is deficient in Cori's disease - Type III glycogen storage disease (GSD) in which hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and growth retardation can be seen.

questions.text: Which among the following aids in supination and pronation of the forearm?
questions.solution:
Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples

Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints

5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the effect of the mutation causing sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Sickle cell anemia is characterized by the replacement of glutamate by valine at the 6th position.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to the T-to-A point mutation in the sixth codon of the β-globin gene. This results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This leads to the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Painful bone crisis- hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    • Adolescence or early adulthood- auto splenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features include priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

 The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled RBCs on peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike.

Disease-modifying drugs such as hydroxyurea can be given to patients with sickle cell anemia since it reduces the incidence of adverse vaso-occlusive vents. Blood transfusions are used to treat and prevent complications of sickle cell disease, including preparation for surgery, symptomatic anemia, acute stroke, multi-organ failure, and acute chest syndrome
