questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition shown in the graph.
questions.solution:
The above graph is called a 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot and it represents noncompetitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition: When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition,

  • Vmax decreases.(1/Vmax increases)
  • Km remains constant.

In a Lineweaver-Burk Plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.

Competitive inhibition - Here, the inhibitor is a structural analog of the substrate. Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme. Here Vmax is unchanged (same y-intercept), and Km is increased (− 1/Km moves closer to zero from a negative value).

Uncompetitive inhibition  - Here, the inhibitor does not have any affinity for the free enzyme. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, but not to the free enzyme. Here, both Vmax and Km are decreased.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A 34-year-old HIV-positive male presented with low-grade fever, cough, night sweats, and weight loss for the past 3 weeks. In view of TB investigations, the Mantoux test was negative, chest X-ray showed non-specific findings and an adequate amount of sputum could not be collected for slide examination. Which of the following is used to diagnose latent TB infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
The test used to diagnose latent TB infection in this patient is the Interferon-gamma release assay(IGRA).

TB test done on a whole blood sample is IGRA. In this test, sensitized T lymphocytes (from whole blood) of suspected individuals, are exposed to highly specific M. tuberculosis antigens such as CFP –10 and ESAT 6. This releases the cytokine IFN- gamma into the blood, which is then measured. It has been evaluated for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in HIV patients (who frequently have a negative Mantoux test.

 IGRAs that have been approved by the US (FDA) are

  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold In-Tube test (QFT-GIT): It quantitates the amount of interferon-gamma produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • T-SPOT.TB test (T-Spot): It determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing Interferon-gamma.
  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus)

IGRAs are more specific than Tuberculin Skin Testing (TST) because of less cross-reactivity to BCG vaccination and sensitization by nontuberculous mycobacteria.

There are 3 described methods for tuberculin skin testing (TST):

  • Mantoux test, also known as the Pirquet test (preferred method)
  • Heaf test
  • Tine test

The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB and resistance to rifampicin in one hour. This test uses a sputum sample and only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required.

Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis. Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen is a lipopolysaccharide present in the mycobacterial cell wall, released from metabolically active cells or degenerating cells of patients having tuberculosis. Urine LAM is a useful tool in diagnosing tuberculosis, especially in patients with HIV and a low CD 4 count. 

QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T cell responses to TB specific antigens.

questions.text: A young boy suffers trauma to his right eye and develops monocular diplopia. What is the most likely cause for his symptom?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for the boy's symptom is iridodialysis. 

Iridodialysis refers to the detachment of the iris root from the ciliary body and is associated with a D-shaped pupil. A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery at the site of detachment.

Causes of Uniocular Diplopia:

  1. Refractive errors
  2. Dry eye syndrome
  3. Corneal abnormalities
  4. Cataracts
  5. Retinal disorders

Causes of Binocular Diplopia:

  1. Strabismus
  2. Cranial nerve palsy
  3. Graves' disease
  4. Trauma or injury
  5. Multiple sclerosis
  6. Myasthenia gravis
 Other options:
  • Festooned pupil - It is seen in posterior synechiae with the adhesion of the pupillary margin to the lens capsule.
  • Iris bombe refers to the forward bowing of the iris seen in closed-angle glaucoma with irido-lenticular contact and in seclusio pupillae with 360-degree posterior synechiae. Drainage of aqueous is blocked due to the irido-lenticular apposition and pressure of the accumulated aqueous causes the iris to bow forward.
  • Iridodonesis refers to a tremulous iris caused by a lack of support. It is seen in pseudophakia after cataract surgery and in lens dislocation.

questions.text: Postmortem examination of a dead body reveals contraction of the hands with absent primary relaxation. What is this suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Postmortem examination of a dead body with contraction of the hands and the absence of primary relaxation is suggestive of cadaveric spasm.

Cadaveric spasm/Instantaneous rigor is a phenomenon where a group of muscles that are in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death till molecular death occurs. It occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation. 

It is most commonly seen in voluntary muscles, especially hands. It is seen in cases of death associated with emotional disturbances like cases of excitement, fear, severe pain, and exhaustion at the time of death. It is an antemortem phenomenon and it indicates the manner of death and not the time since death.

 

Other options: 

Option A: Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. The order of appearance of rigor mortis: Myocardium of the heart is affected first. Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. It starts in the eyelids, neck, lower jaw, and muscles of the face and progresses downwards to involve the muscles of the chest, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs. The fingers and toes are affected last.

Option B: Livor mortis/Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the dermis. It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to the stagnation of blood in the vessels of the dependent parts due to the effect of gravity. 

Option D: Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. The body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection after death. 

Related Pearl: Difference between Cadaveric Rigidity (Rigor mortis) and Cadaveric Spasm (Instantaneous rigor)

Trait Cadaveric rigidity Cadaveric spasm
Production Freezing and exposure to temperature above 650C will produce rigor Cannot be produced by any method after death
Mechanism Reduction of ATP Not clear
Predisposing factors Nil Sudden death, excitement, fear etc
Time of onset 1 – 2 hours after death Instantaneous
Muscles involved All muscles – both voluntary and involuntary Single group of voluntary muscles
Muscle stiffening Not marked: can be overcome by moderate force Marked: Great force is required to overcome
Molecular death Occurs Doesn't occur
Body heat Cold Warm
Electrical stimuli Muscles do not respond Muscles respond
Muscular reaction Acidic Alkaline
Medicolegal importance Indicates time of death Indicates manner of death

questions.text: A patient underwent a left submandibular gland excision during which the hypoglossal nerve was injured. Which of the following deficits would be seen in this case?

choices.text: Deviated tongue to the contralateral side
Deviated tongue to the same side
Loss of taste in posterior 1/3rd of the tongue

questions.solution:
A hypoglossal nerve injury would damage all muscles of the tongue except the palatoglossus resulting in deviation of the tongue to the same side. Since, the left hypoglossal nerve is injured in the above scenario, the tongue will deviate to the left side. 

Hypoglossal nerve injury:

  • Ipsilateral tongue atrophy
  • Paralysis of all muscles except palatoglossus resulting in ipsilateral deviation of the tongue on protrusion
  • Paralysis of geniohyoid and thyrohyoid resulting in deviation of larynx to the contralateral side.

questions.text: The lab technician notices a urine sample from a 4-year-old male that was normal on collection but turns into the colour shown in the image after a few hours. It further darkened over the next few hours. Deficiency of which of the following can cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Urine turning dark in colour on long-standing is a characteristic feature of alkaptonuria caused by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.

The dark colour of the urine on standing is due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogentisic acid.

Features of alkaptonuria:

  • It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase.
  • Large amounts of homogentisic acid are formed, which are excreted in urine or deposited in tissues.
  • Clinical manifestations of alkaptonuria consist of ochronosis and arthritis in adulthood. Arthritis predominantly involves the spine, hip, and knee. Radiologically, it is characterized by intervertebral calcifications.

Ochronosis : Bluish black discoloration of sclera and ear cartilage due to deposition of homogentisic acid, beginning in late adolescence.

Other options:

A. Beta-carotene: Beta-carotene is a pigment that can give a yellow or orange color to certain foods and, to some extent, can affect the color of urine. However, beta-carotene deficiency is not associated with the darkening of urine on long-standing. It is not a characteristic feature of beta-carotene deficiency.

B. Tyrosine aminotransferase: Tyrosine aminotransferase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of the amino acid tyrosine. However, deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase is not known to cause darkening of urine on long-standing. Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency is a very rare condition and is associated with symptoms related to impaired tyrosine metabolism, such as neurological and developmental issues.

C. L-ascorbic acid: L-ascorbic acid, also known as vitamin C, is an antioxidant and plays a role in various metabolic processes. While high doses of vitamin C supplements can sometimes cause changes in urine color, such as a more yellow or orange hue, deficiency of L-ascorbic acid is not associated with darkening of urine on long-standing. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) is characterized by symptoms such as fatigue, joint pain, and skin changes.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presented with the following lesion in his eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Bitot's spot, a pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia.

Bitot's spot is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva which is usually bilateral. The most common site is temporal.

Ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency include loss of sensitivity to green light (earliest to appear), nyctalopia (night blindness), and xerophthalmia.

Xerophthalmia includes conjunctival xerosis (dryness) with Bitot’s spots (white patches of keratinized epithelium appearing on the sclera), corneal ulcers, and keratomalacia (softening of the cornea) that leads to corneal scarring and ultimately, blindness.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presented to the clinic with complaints of  episodic vertigo,  sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What is the possible clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The possible clinical diagnosis for a 35-year-old male presenting with episodic vertigo, ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and low-tone roaring tinnitus is Meniere's disease. It is also called endolymphatic hydrops.

The primary pathology in Ménière’s disease is the distension of the endolymphatic system due to an increased endolymph volume. This can result either from increased production of endolymph or its faulty absorption or both. Normally, endolymph secreted by stria vascularis, fills the membranous labyrinth, and is absorbed through the endolymphatic sac.

Meniere's disease is a chronic condition of the inner ear that affects balance and hearing. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, which are brief and intense episodes of spinning dizziness. Patients may also experience a sense of pressure or fullness in the affected ear, along with fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus (ringing or buzzing in the ear). The tinnitus associated with Meniere's disease is typically low-tone roaring in nature.

Other options:

  • Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is another common cause of vertigo, but it is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo triggered by specific head movements, such as rolling over in bed or looking up. BPPV does not typically cause ear pressure, hearing loss, or low-tone roaring tinnitus.
  • Labyrinthitis is an inflammation of the inner ear, usually caused by a viral or bacterial infection. It can cause vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus, but it is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as ear pain, fever, and a general feeling of illness.
  • Syncope refers to a temporary loss of consciousness and muscle tone, often caused by a decrease in blood flow to the brain. It is not associated with the symptoms described in the scenario, such as vertigo, ear pressure, hearing loss, or tinnitus.

questions.text: What is the reason that hemoglobin cannot pass through the glomerulus in a normal physiological state?

choices.text: It is a large molecule bounded with another protein.
It gets attracted to the positive charge of the glomerular filtration barrier.

questions.solution:
The haemoglobin (Hb) cannot pass through the glomerulus in a normal physiological state because it is a large molecule bound with another protein.

The Hb molecule released into the blood from RBCs is immediately bound by a protein called haptoglobin (size: 12.4 nm). It forms the haemoglobin-haptoglobin complex which is large enough to be prevented from crossing the glomerular filtration barrier.  

Free haemoglobin undergoes extensive glomerular filtration, which is blocked by Haptoglobin. The filtration of Hb leads to renal tubule iron deposition (brown) and hemoglobinuria. This is prevented by the sequestration of Hb by haptoglobin.

Another reason is because of the negative charge of Hb. Both the Hb and glomerular filtration barrier are negatively charged. Hence Hb is repelled away from the filtration barrier. 

The glomerular filtration barrier consists of:

  • The endothelium of the capillary
  • A basement membrane - contains type IV collagen, glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge. 
  • A layer of epithelial cells (podocytes) surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membrane.

The capillary endothelium is perforated by thousands of small holes called fenestrae, which measure from 4 nm up to 8nm. Therefore, neutral substances with molecular diameters of less than 4 nm are freely filtered, and filtration of those with diameters of more than 8 nm approaches zero.

In addition to the size of the particles, the filtration also depends mainly on the charge of the particle being filtered. The glomerular capillary wall consists of highly negatively charged proteins called sialoproteins, which repel the negatively charged substances (anions). The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which will repel most of the negative charges (anionic substances). Whereas, the cationic substances are easily filtered.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypocalcemia, thymic hypoplasia, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 ?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of hypocalcemia, developmental defect of the thymus, cardiac abnormalities, and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 are suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome.

In this syndrome, the fourth branchial arch and the derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches (which contribute to the formation of the thymus, parathyroids, and heart) develop abnormally. This syndrome is therefore associated with multiple deficits (memorable through the mnemonic CATCH - 22)

Mnemonic CATCH-22:

  • Cardiac abnormality
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia
  • Cleft palate
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Deletion 22q11.2  

Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity can manifest as:

  • T cells are absent in the lymph nodes, spleen, and peripheral blood, and infants with this defect are extremely vulnerable to viral, fungal, and protozoal infections.
  • Patients also are susceptible to infection with intracellular bacteria, because of defective T cell-mediated immunity.
  • B cells and serum immunoglobulins are generally unaffected.

 Other options:

Option A: Pitt syndrome or Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome or Pitt–Rogers–Danks syndrome (PRDS) occurs due to partial deletion or monosomy of chromosome 4. The main features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome are typical “Greek helmet” facies secondary to ocular hypertelorism, prominent glabella, and frontal bossing and microcephaly.

Option B: Williams syndrome occurs due to deletion at chromosome 7. Classical facial features include:

  • Periorbital fullness of subcutaneous tissues,
  • Hypertelorism,
  • A stellate pattern of the iris,
  • Long philtrum,
  • Thick vermillion border of the lips,
  • Wide mouth,
  • Small jaw (elfin facies)

Option D: Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by the partial deletion of the short arm of Chromosome no.5. Affected children have a cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms as shown in the image below: 1) shows the site of the lesion,  2) has loss of proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch on the same side, and 3) has loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion on the contralateral side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image along with the features above is diagnostic of Brown Sequard syndrome.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion, at which hemisection of the cord is seen.

The part marked as 2 is the ipsilateral side of the lesion, which has the following features:

  • Loss of proprioception and vibration
  • Loss of discriminative touch
  • Weakness and spastic type of paralysis in certain muscle groups

The part marked as 3 is the contralateral side of the lesion and exhibits the following features:

  • Loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion

questions.text: The students of a boarding school eat from the same canteen. One of the students developed abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever following which other students also presented with similar symptoms. Which of the following investigations should the Medical Officer of the area check for to reach a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of a Hepatitis A outbreak that is spread via the fecal-oral route and the investigation of choice is IgM for Hepatitis A.

Hepatitis A:

Modes of transmission

  • Fecal-oral route: This is the major route of transmission. It can occur directly (handshake after toilet) or indirectly via contaminated food, water, or milk.
  • Parenteral route: This is very rare and occurs during the viral dissemination phase. It occurs during the prodromal phase and not when patients are symptomatic and admitted to the hospital. As a result, healthcare workers are not at increased risk.
  • Sexual transmission may occur in individuals practicing oro-anal methods (usually homosexual men). It however would not cause an outbreak.

Incubation period:

  • 10 to 50 days (usually 14-28 days). Isolation is not an effective measure to control outbreaks as the shedding of the virus is maximum during the early stages of illness when clinical illness may not have started and many patients are asymptomatic yet continue to shed the virus.

Clinical spectrum:

  • The onset of jaundice is preceded by gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever.
  • Jaundice may appear within a few days of the prodromal period, but anicteric hepatitis is more common.
  • Hepatitis A resolves completely in 98 percent of cases but relapse of symptoms is noted in 3-20 percent of cases

Diagnosis:

  • Laboratory diagnosis of hepatitis A can be obtained by
    • Demonstration of HAV particles or specific viral antigens in the feces, bile, and blood.
    • Anti-HAV appears in the lgM fraction during the acute phase, peaking about 2 weeks after the elevation of liver enzymes. ELISA is the method of choice for measuring HAV antibodies.

Prevention and containment:

  • Control of reservoir: Use of 0.5 percent sodium hypochlorite has been strongly recommended as an effective disinfectant
  • Control of transmission: personal and community hygiene. Hand hygiene before food and after the toilet is highly recommended.
  • 1 mg/L of free residual chlorine can cause the destruction of the virus in 30 minutes at pH values of 8.5 or less. Hence adequate chlorination can be helpful.
  • Patients with chronic liver disease are at increased risk for fulminant hepatitis A and should be vaccinated. The use of the hepatitis A vaccine should be considered for pre-exposure(for travelers) and post-exposure(close contacts of affected individuals)prophylaxis.

Related Pearl: The Hepatitis Viruses

questions.text: Lung malignancy is most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis is most commonly associated with Mesotheliomas,  pleural malignancy. 

Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Pleural effusion
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Laryngeal, ovarian and colon carcinomas

Asbestosis:

  • Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis that occurs after 5-10 years of exposure to asbestos. However, once established, it progresses even in the further removal of the worker from its contact. Asbestosis affects the basal part of the lung causing diffuse peribronchial fibrosis.
  • Asbestos is of 2 types i.e Serpentine/Chrysolite variety and Amphibole type
  • Amphibole type has the following varieties:
    • Crocidolite(blue)
    • Amosite(brown)
    • Anthrophyllite(white)
  • Sputum shows asbestos body, which are asbestos fibres coated with fibrin.
  • They present with cough and exertional dyspnoea and predominantly affects the lower lobes of the lung, in contrast to other forms of pneumoconiosis, which affect the upper lobes.
  • Pulmonary function testing in asbestosis typically shows a restrictive pattern with a decrease in both lung volumes and diffusing capacity.
  • X-ray shows peripheral reticular opacities predominantly in the lower zones. HRCT shows subpleural fibrotic lines, irregular opacities, traction bronchiectasis and honeycombing. Lung parenchymal involvement occurs after years of exposure (at least 10 years).
  • The complications that can occur are
    • Pulmonary fibrosis 
    • Carcinoma of the lung 
    • Malignancy of the Gastrointestinal tract
    • Mesothelioma of the pleura

Preventive measures:

  • Using a safer type of Asbestos (chrysolite and amosite)
  • Substituting other insulants like glass fibre, mineral wool, calcium silicate, plastic foams etc
  • Dust control
  • Periodic examination of workers
  • Continuing research

questions.text: Which of the following dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary?
questions.solution:
The venous sinus marked with 'B' in the given image is the straight sinus. The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

The straight sinus is a continuation of the inferior sagittal sinus. It lies in the junction of the falx cerebri with tentorium cerebelli. The straight sinus further drains into one of the transverse sinuses (mostly the left).

Other options

A - Superior sagittal sinus

C - Superior petrosal sinus

D - Sigmoid sinus

Transverse sinus continue as sigmoid sinus

questions.text: In ORS, sodium is given along with glucose to facilitate___?
questions.solution:
In ORS, sodium is given along with glucose to facilitate co-transport.

Glucose co transported with sodium is an example of Secondary Active transport.

The glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and sodium in a 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO oral rehydration solution (ORS). The low osmolarity of the ORS in the lumen as compared to the blood facilitate absorption of fluid and hence the electrolytes due to the solvent drag.

The low-osmolality World Health Organization (WHO) oral rehydration solution (ORS) is now the global standard of care in the management of acute gastroenteritis. 

Note:

Types of transport:

  • Active transport:
    • Primary
      • Energy is derived from the transporter itself. Eg Na+ K+ ATPase pump.
    • Secondary:
      • Energy is derived indirectly. Eg. SGLT – Sodium linked glucose transport
  • Passive transport
    • Simple:
      • No energy is required.
      • No carrier molecule is involved.
      • Eg. O2 exchange in alveoli.
    • Facilitated:
      • No energy is required.
      • Carrier molecule involved.
      • Eg. Glucose transport by GLUT transporters.

Related Pearl: Composition of reduced osmolarity Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)

The composition of reduced-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS) is as follows:

Reduced- osmolarity ORS mmol/L
Sodium  75 
Chloride 65
Glucose (anhydrous) 75
Potassium 20
Citrate 10
Total Osmolarity 245

questions.text: A child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On examination, you notice inspiratory stridor in the child and laryngeal examination is as below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with inspiratory stridor and Omega-shaped epiglottis has laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in newborns. It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. On examination, the omega-shaped epiglottis is seen.

Factors increasing Stridor in laryngomalacia:

  • Supine Position
  • Sleep
  • Agitation
  • URI (Upper Respiratory tract Infection)

Stridor is increased on crying but subsides on placing the child in a prone position; crying is normal. 

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Treatment is mainly conservative. Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. In cases of severe laryngomalacia, supraglottoplasty is done.

questions.text: Microanuerysms are seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Among the following microaneurysms are seen in diabetic retinopathy.

Microaneurysms are localized, saccular outpouchings of the capillary wall that are formed either by focal dilatation of the capillary wall where pericytes are absent or by fusion of two arms of a capillary loop.

  • Most develop in the inner capillary plexus (inner nuclear layer), frequently adjacent to areas of capillary non-perfusion.
  • Loss of pericytes may also lead to endothelial cell proliferation with the formation of ‘cellular’ microaneurysms.
  • Microaneurysms may leak plasma constituents into the retina as a result of a breakdown in the blood-retinal barrier or may thrombose.
  • They tend to be the earliest sign of DR.

Stages and fundus picture in diabetic retinopathy:

Non-proliferative/ Background Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • Microaneurysms 
  • Dot and Blot hemorrhages 
  • Exudates

Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (indicates progressive retinal ischemia):

  • Intra-retinal microvascular abnormalities
  • Venous changes (such as beading)
  • Cotton wool spots
  • Deep retinal hemorrhages

Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:

  • NeoVascularization of the Optic Disc (NVD)
  • NeoVascularization Elsewhere in the periphery of the fundus (NVE)

Advanced Diabetic Eye Disease:

  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Neovascular glaucoma

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A patient developed the following deformity, after overhead (weight-lifting) exercises. Which of the following muscle is involved?
questions.solution:
The image shows winging of the scapula which is pulled upwards and towards the spine. This is due to paralysis of the serratus anterior which is supplied by the long thoracic nerve.

When the patient is asked to push against a wall with both hands, the medial border of the scapula on the affected side becomes prominent and this is known as ‘winging of the scapula.’

Scapular winging is almost always caused by damage to one of three nerves that control muscles in your arms, back, and neck:

  • The long thoracic nerve, which controls the serratus anterior muscle
  • The dorsal scapular nerve, which controls the rhomboid muscles
  • The spinal accessory nerve, which controls the trapezius muscle

 The muscles of the back and their innervation are:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with multiple sexual partners presents with a palmoplantar rash as seen below. On examination, he has epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario of maculopapular rash with flu-like symptoms and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy points to secondary syphilis.

Secondary syphilis occurs within 6 weeks to 8 weeks of the onset of the primary chancre.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Onset of systemic manifestations includes symptoms such as malaise, headache, loss of appetite, sore throat
  • Generalized symmetric, asymptomatic maculopapular rash on the palms and soles.
  • Generalized adenopathy in 50% of cases
  • Condyloma lata is the classic finding. They are highly contagious exophytic broad excrescences that ulcer­ate. These are commonly seen on the vulva, perianal area, and upper thighs.

The image below shows mucosal and cutaneous lesion of secondary syphilis.

Other options:

Option A: Psoriasis presents with itching and a papulosquamous rash commonly on the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs. The lesions are red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin. They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone called the Woronoff ring.

Option C: Meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitidis presents as acute fever with chills, malaise, and prostration. A petechial rash is seen early in the disease. Metastatic involvement of the joints, ears, eyes, lungs, and adrenals may occur. 

Option D: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe mucocutaneous reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, where SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

  • Primary Syphilis:

Chancre- Painless, indurated, usually single

Lymphadenopathy- Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

Dory flop sign- As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

 

Secondary Syphilis:

A & B: Generalized rash(non-itchy, no vesicles, and palm and sole involvement).

This is the most common lesion.

C & D: Condyloma lata.

E: Moth-eaten alopecia (Non-scarring)

F: Mucous patches(Flat erosions on the tongue which can coalesce and form snail track ulcers).These are the most infectious lesions.

G: Pigmentary plaques

H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Tertiary Syphilis:

Gummatous syphilis(deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor)

Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

CVS-Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

CNS-General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

 

Latent Syphilis-Period between secondary and tertiary syphilis, when the patient is asymptomatic clinically, and only serological evidence of infection is present.

  • Early latent- Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent- After 1 year of infection

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is deficient in the autosomal recessive type of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency is the first immunodeficiency disease associated with enzyme deficiency in SCID (Severe combined immunodeficiency).

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive.
  • Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jiroveci, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA).
  • Deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP), which are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes than of B lymphocytes.
  • In the two most common forms (γc mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

X-linked SCID.

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.  
  • X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

Other options:

Option A – Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency causes increased ammonia concentrations causing ataxia and death. It is one of the most common urea cycle disorders.

Option B– Phosphomannose isomerase deficiency is a disorder of glycosylation and features include failure to thrive, enteropathy, and hepatic fibrosis.

Option D-Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HPRT) enzyme deficiency leads to a disease called Lesch-Nyhan disease (LND)

questions.text: The SAFE strategy given by WHO forms the mainstay of the management of trachoma. What does the S in this acronym represent?
questions.solution:
The S in the acronym stands for surgery.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFEstrategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the TRIC (trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis) serovars A, B, Ba, C. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage. The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles contain Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • Corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

The cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. The patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed Herbert follicles)
  • Corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

The below image shows Herbert's pits. 

There can be associated trichiasis ( when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with `FISTO’ is in use.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A student presented with urticaria after she ate some seafood. She wants a non-sedating drug as she has an exam to study for. Which of the following drugs would you prefer to prescribe to her?
questions.solution:
The student is suffering from urticaria and fexofenadine can be prescribed to her. This is preferred as it is a second-generation antihistamine having minimal/no sedative effects as it cannot cross the blood-brain barrier easily.

Pheniramine, promethazine, and hydroxyzine are first-generation antihistamines that should not be prescribed to drivers and heavy machine workers because they are lipophilic cross the blood-brain barrier easily and cause sedation. 

Highly sedative first-generation antihistamines:

  • Diphenhydramine
  • Dimenhydrinate
  • Promethazine
  • Hydroxyzine

Second-generation antihistamines- They are less sedative because of less central nervous system penetration and do not block autonomic receptors. They include:

  • Fexofenadine
  • Loratadine, Desloratadine
  • Cetirizine, Levocetirizine
  • Azelastine, Mizolastine, Ebastine
  • Olopatadine
  • Rupatadine

questions.text: A newborn baby brought by the mother with complaints of the left upper eyelid moving up and down during breastfeeding or thumb sucking which disappears when the baby is not being fed. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.

Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking syndrome:

  • About 5% of all cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.
  • The vast majority are unilateral.
  • Etiology: a branch of the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle.
  • Signs
    • Retraction of the ptotic lid with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement.
    • Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth.
    • Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it.

The following image shows a woman with Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. See how her right eyelid ptosis retracts with the opening of the mouth.

Other options:

Option A: In 3rd nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve) - Due to the involvement of the superior rectus and medial rectus, elevation and adduction will also be impaired, which is not the case here.

Option B: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder associated with a decrease in postsynaptic depolarization due to the blocking of acetylcholine receptors by autoantibodies. It is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. 

Option C: In lagophthalmos, there is incomplete closure of the palpable aperture when the patient attempts to close the eyes due to congenital deformity, paralysis of the orbicularis muscle, ectropion or contraction of the lid.  It may be due to a malfunction of the facial nerve. Treatment includes the management of exposure keratopathy with frequent instillation of lubricants.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of continuous diarrhoea that started 20 hours ago and is rice watery in consistency.He is drowsy and unresponsive. His eyes are sunken and skin turgor is poor.What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The rice watery stools along with the other clinical features are suggestive of Vibrio cholerae infection.

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, rice water stools- watery diarrhoea with flecks of mucus, associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary oedema and arrhythmias are some of the complications. 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhoea. 

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following arises from 6th pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Ductus arteriosus arises from the 6th pharngeal arch.

Pharyngeal arches appear in the 4th or 5th week of development and contribute to the formation of the head and neck region. They are formed as a series of 6 thickenings in the cranial most part of the foregut (the future pharynx). They are craniocaudally numbered from I to VI. The 5th pharyngeal arch disappears, so only 5 arches remain. 

  • The first pharyngeal arch is also known as the mandibular arch.
  • The second pharyngeal arch is also known as the hyoid arch.
  • The 3rd, 4th, and 6th pharyngeal arches have no special names.

Other options:

Medial pterygoids,Lateral pterygoids,Tensor veli palatini- all arise from first pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: The best way to plot trends in the incidence of diarrheal disease in a given area is by?
questions.solution:
Line graphs or line diagrams are the best way to plot trends in the incidence of a disease in a given area.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A child after eating an unknown fruit ,has been brought to your emergency department with the following signs and symptoms - Dry mouth, irrelevant slurred speech, dry and hot skin, dilated pupils. On examination there was tachycardia and hyperthermia.What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical syndrome in the question is that of Datura poisoning.

Dhatura:

Active principle:

  • Scopolamine
  • Hyoscyamine
  • Trace amount of atropine
  • The active principle called “Dhaturine” on heating would yield atropine
  • Seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked and produce delirium, hallucinations, and seizures along with other classic anticholinergic effects, such as mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth and skin, blurred vision, urinary retention, and hyperthermia.

Mode of Action:

  • Anticholinergic

Toxic manifestations of Datura:

  • Mnemonic: "hot as a hare, blind as a bat, dry as a bone, red as a beet, and mad as a hatter"
  • Also, remember the D's of Datura
    • Dry hot skin (Temp rises upto 42 C, a scarlet rash may also be appreciated).
    • Dilatation of pupils along with loss of accommodation
    • Diplopia
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat, unquenchable thirst
    • Dysphagia
    • Dilatation of cutaneous blood vessels
    • Dysarthria (Difficulty in talking)
    • Drunken gait
    • Delirium
    • Drowsiness
    • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

Treatment

  • Gastric emptying is often delayed, and the small, plentiful seeds can become trapped among the gastrointestinal folds after ingestion; thus gastric decontamination can be an important therapy.
  • Physostigmine in severe toxicity given 1-2 mg IM/IV after every half hour as required. It is a physiological antidote. Pilocarpine may also be given.

Note:

In India, datura is employed mainly as a stupefying poison prior to robbery, kidnapping and rape. It is sometimes known as rail-road poison, as it is commonly encountered during a journey. Many a time, robbers disguised as saints offer ‘prasad’ mixed with dhatura seeds and rob the passengers.

questions.text: A patient on anti-cancer therapy developed an infection. Blood analysis revealed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is likely to be effective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Filgrastim is the drug used in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced neutropenia.

Filgrastim is a recombinant human G-CSF(granulocyte-colony stimulating factor), that stimulates CFU-G(colony-forming unit- granulocyte) to increase neutrophil production. It is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion. It is indicated in: 

  • The treatment of severe neutropenia after autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation and high-dose cancer chemotherapy.
  • The treatment of severe congenital neutropenias.
  • The treatment of neutropenia of patients with AIDS receiving zidovudine.

Important adverse reactions include bone pain, local skin reaction, and cutaneous necrotizing vasculitis.

Other options:

Option A: Romiplostim is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist. It is used in the management of immune thrombocytopenic purpura(ITP). 

Option B: Oprelvekin is a recombinant human IL-11. It stimulates hematopoiesis. It is used in the treatment of thrombocytopenia due to non-myeloid malignancies. Important adverse effects are fluid retention, tachycardia, palpitation, edema, and shortness of breath.

Option D: Epoetin alfa is a recombinant human erythropoietin analogue that stimulates red blood cell production. It is used in the treatment of anaemias associated with surgery, chronic kidney disease, AIDS, cancer chemotherapy, prematurity, and certain chronic inflammatory conditions.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as 'C'.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'C', is the Epiglottis.

The structures marked in the image are:

  1. Hyoid bone
  2. Thyroid cartilage
  3. Epiglottis
  4. Cricoid cartilage

The laryngeal skeleton is formed by a series of cartilages that are connected by ligaments and fibrous membranes:

  • The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages consist of hyaline cartilage.
  • The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage consist of elastic cartilage.
  • The hyoid bone is a 'U-shaped' bone suspended from the tips of the styloid processes by the stylohyoid ligaments.

questions.text: The  fallopian tube is lined by ______.
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the fallopian tube is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. 

The ciliated epithelial cells are predominant in the distal part of the fallopian tube. There is an increase in the height and number of cilia in these cells during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle.

Other cells in the fallopian tube epithelium include:

  • Secretory or peg cells - maximally located in the proximal portion of the tube. These cells are active around the time of ovulation, and their secretions help in the capacitation of sperms.
  • Intraepithelial lymphocytes - may present occasionally. 

 

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum:
    • The widest part

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms. 

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Which among the following does the graph given below depict?
questions.solution:
The graph given above depicts the Haldane effect.

The Haldane effect occurs when the partial pressure of O2 is higher as in the lungs.

Binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from hemoglobin. This is because the binding of O2 to the hemoglobin makes it a stronger acid. This causes the carbaminohemoglobin to dissociate and releases the CO2 from the hemoglobin. CO2 is then eliminated from the lungs.

In the given graph, when the partial pressure of O2 is higher ( 100 mmHg), as in capillaries of lungs, the CO2 dissociation curve shifts to the right (the amount of CO2 in the blood decreases, as it is expired out).

Thus, the Haldane effect approximately doubles the amount of CO2 eliminated from the blood in the lungs and approximately doubles the pickup of CO2 from the tissues.

 

Other options:

  • Option A: Bohr effect: Decrease in the binding of O2 to hemoglobin (Shift of O2 dissociation curve to the right) in the presence of raised CO2 and low PH. This enhances O2-hemoglobin binding in the lungs and decreases O2 binding in the tissues. 
  • Option B: Henry's Law in Respiration: The amount of oxygen that dissolves into the bloodstream is directly proportional to the partial pressure of oxygen in alveolar air.
  • Option D: Boyle's Law: The pressure of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to its volume if its temperature is kept constant.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man living in Nellore, Andhra Pradesh presents with the following lesions on his teeth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image along with the endemic area of Andhra Pradesh is diagnostic of Dental fluorosis.

Dental fluorosis (also termed mottled enamel) is an extremely common disorder, characterized by hypomineralization of tooth enamel caused by ingestion of excessive fluoride during enamel formation.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic in parts of India- Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Nalgonda, Prakasam), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Tamil Nadu. 

Mechanism:

  • In the extra-cellular environment of maturing enamel, an excess of fluoride ions alters the rate at which enamel matrix proteins (amelogenin) are enzymatically broken down and the rate at which the subsequent breakdown products are removed.
  • Fluoride may also indirectly alter the action of protease via a decrease in the availability of free calcium ions in the mineralization environment.
  • This results in the formation of enamel with less mineralization.
  • This hypomineralized enamel has altered optical properties and appears opaque and lustreless relative to normal enamel.

Classification:

The two main classification systems which are used in the grading of severity of dental fluorosis are Dean’s system and TF system.

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis: (1.5mg/L) Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. Best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects only permanent teeth. It causes mottling on dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white patches on the teeth, and loss of shine in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and can even become brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a corroded appearance. 
  • Skeletal fluorosis: (3-6mg/L) Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone and these are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis: (>10mg/L) Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • Chemical treatment in a water treatment plant can be moderately expensive. The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to detect blood stains?
questions.solution:
Barberio's test is not used for detecting blood stains. It helps in the identification of semen.

Barberio's test is used to detect the presence of spermine picrate, a component of prostatic secretion. A drop of the stain of spermatic fluid taken in a glass slide is charged with a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid. Under microscopic examination, the needle-shaped yellowish spermine picrate crystals indicate the presence of semen.

Option B: Takayama's test- It is also known as the hemochromogen crystal test. It is a more reliable test to detect old blood stains. 2-3 drops of Takayama's reagent are added to the suspected material on the glass slide. A positive test result is indicated by the presence of pink feathery crystals of reduced hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin in clusters.

Option C: Teichman's test- This test is also used to detect blood stains. It is also called as hemin crystal test. A small crystal of sodium chloride and glacial acetic acid is used for the test. Faint yellowish-red to brownish crystals of hemin or hematin chloride in clusters are seen if the suspected material is stained with blood. Teichman's test may be negative if the blood stain is old. 

Option D: Spectroscopy-  It is the most reliable test to detect the presence of both old and recent blood stains. Characteristic dark bands are produced depending on the type of blood pigment when the blood solution is examined under a spectroscope. 

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate were seen. What is the most important risk factor for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis and the most important risk factor among these is diabetes. 

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic mycosis. It is typically seen in patients with diabetes mellitus and/or diabetic ketoacidosis, and immunocompromised patients. Mucormycosis recently emerged as an important superinfection in COVID-19 patients, especially in India. The surge in cases is most likely due to diabetes mellitus and steroid use.

Risk factors for the infection include the following:

  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Acidosis (especially diabetic ketoacidosis)
  • Steroid treatment
  • Lymphomas and leukemias
  • Immunodeficiencies
  • Severe burns 

The rhino-orbital-cerebral is the most common form of mucormycosis. Patients present with rhinitis, eye or facial pain, and facial numbness followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and swelling along with blurry vision. 

Patients can have local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembling the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discoloration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis is made by biopsy with histopathologic examination. The biopsy shows characteristic wide, ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

The below image shows biopsy findings seen in mucormycosis.

Treatment includes intravenous administration of amphotericin B and wide excision of necrotic tissues. Along with the reversal of underlying conditions and risk factors.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman who presented to the clinic with a lump in her right breast is diagnosed to have breast carcinoma. All of the following are favorable prognostic markers except ______.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario explains breast carcinoma and HER2 overexpression is associated with poor survival.

The main importance of HER2 status is as a predictor of response to agents that target this receptor. Luminal A subtype i.e well-differentiated, ER-positive, HER2-negative, and low proliferation, has the most favorable prognosis.

The proliferative rate can be measured by mitotic counts or by immunohistochemical detection of Ki67 proteins. Carcinomas with high prolifera­tion rates have a poorer prognosis.

questions.text:
A child accidentally took a bottle full of iron tablets. Which drug is used as antidote for poisoning?

DMSA-Dimercaptosuccinic Acid
questions.solution:
The antidote used for iron chelation in acute iron intoxication is deferoxamine.

Deferoxamine is a potent iron-chelating compound with parenteral administration. It binds already absorbed iron and promotes its excretion in urine and faeces. For acute iron toxicity, intramuscular administration is preferred. For chronic iron intoxication (e.g., thalassemia), continuous subcutaneous administration is recommended.

Other options:

Option A: Luspatercept is a medication used to manage and treat anaemia in myelodysplastic syndromes, primary myelofibrosis, and beta-thalassemia.

Option C: Deferiprone and deferasirox are both oral drugs used in the treatment of chronic iron overload due to transfusion. They are not recommended over deferoxamine.

Optio D: DMSA(Dimercaptosuccinic Acid) is the oral agent of choice in lead poisoning.

questions.text: A child on workup is found to be suffering from a rare form of pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency for which he has developed high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the best dietary advice for the patient?

choices.text: High protein and low carbohydrate intake
High carbohydrate and low fat intake
High fat and low carbohydrate intake

questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency(PDH) can be due to a defect in any one/more of the components of the PDH enzyme complex. Patients are advised to follow a high fat and low carbohydrate intake.

In pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, there is a defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex, leading to impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. This results in the accumulation of pyruvate and subsequent conversion to lactate, causing lactic acidosis and high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

To provide an alternative fuel source for the body, patients with pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency are often advised to follow a high-fat and low-carbohydrate diet. By reducing the intake of carbohydrates, which are metabolized to pyruvate, and increasing the intake of fats, which can be metabolized via alternative pathways, the reliance on the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex can be minimized.

Therefore, option C (High fat and low carbohydrate intake) is the most appropriate dietary advice for a patient with pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency and high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Other options:

Option A: High protein and low carbohydrate intake - This option is incorrect because a high protein intake would still involve the metabolism of amino acids, which can contribute to the production of pyruvate and further exacerbate the metabolic acidosis in pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency. 

Option B: High carbohydrate and low-fat intake - This option is incorrect because pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency impairs the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, resulting in the accumulation of pyruvate and subsequent lactic acidosis. 

Option D: Only carbohydrate intake henceforth - This option is incorrect because pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency specifically affects the metabolism of carbohydrates, leading to the accumulation of pyruvate. Relying solely on carbohydrate intake would exacerbate the metabolic acidosis by increasing pyruvate levels.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the abdominal plane labeled 2?
questions.solution:
The structure marked 2 in the given image is the subcostal plane. It is at the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The subcostal plane is an anatomical reference plane used in clinical and surgical practice. It is defined as a horizontal plane passing through the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage bilaterally. The 10th costal cartilage corresponds approximately to the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The costal cartilages are extensions of the ribs that articulate with the sternum anteriorly. The 10th costal cartilage is the cartilage of the 10th rib.

In the given image, structure 2 represents the subcostal plane, which corresponds to the level of the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage. Since the 10th costal cartilage is at the level of the upper border of L3, it indicates that the subcostal plane is also at the level of the upper border of L3.

Other options: As mentioned earlier, the subcostal plane is positioned at the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3), not L1 or L2 or L4.

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions

  • Horizontal planes 
    • L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). Corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). Corresponds to the origin of Inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (Paramedian or lateral planes)
    • Mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Left hypochondriac, Epigastric, Right hypochondriac
  • Left lumbar, Umbilical (Central), Right lumbar
  • Left iliac, Hypogastric (Suprapubic), Right iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • The supracristal plane passing through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. Posteriorly, it corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. When supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle is the angle between the 12th rib and the outer border of Erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle (of Petit) is marked below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar herniation can occur here.

questions.text: What is the affinity of carbon monoxide to hemoglobin in comparison to oxygen?
questions.solution:
CO binds to hemoglobin with an affinity that is 250 times that of O2 to form carboxyhemoglobin. 

CO also increases the O2 affinity of remaining free hemoglobin sites (causes left shift of the O2 - hemoglobin dissociation curve).

  • Curve A - Myoglobin O2-dissociation curve
  • Curve B - Normal Hb O2-dissociation curve
  • Curve C- CO binds to hemoglobin and prevents O2 binding
  • Curve D - Anemia

Carbon monoxide (CO) reacts with hemoglobin to form carbon monoxyhemoglobin (carboxyhemoglobin or COHb). The affinity of hemoglobin for CO is 210 times its affinity for O2, and COHb liberates CO very slowly. An additional difficulty is that when COHb is present, the dissociation curve of the remaining HbO2 shifts to the left, decreasing the amount of O2 released.

Treatment of CO poisoning consists of ventilation with oxygen since oxygen hastens the dissociation of carboxyhemoglobin.

questions.text: In the following LV pressure-volume loop diagram, point C denotes  ______
questions.solution:
The mitral valve will close at point B.

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml, called the end-diastolic volume and the diastolic pressure rising to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

During isovolumic contraction, the volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. The line labeled “IV” traces this decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled “EW”) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

questions.text: Nitrogenous waste is excreted from the body in the form of __?
questions.solution:
Nitrogenous wastes are excreted from the body in the form of urea.

Depending on their ecology and physiology, different animals excrete excess nitrogen as ammonia, uric acid, or urea.

In aqueous animals nitrogenous waste is excreted as ammonia. The constant excretion of water permits them to excrete the highly toxic ammonia, as it highly water soluble. Birds must both conserve water and maintain low weight and hence excreting nitrogen-rich uric acid. Many land animals, including humans, excrete nontoxic, highly water-soluble urea. High blood levels in renal disease are a consequence of impaired renal function.

 

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Which of the following PDE-5 inhibitor is the longest acting?
questions.solution:
Tadalafil is the longest acting PDE-5 inhibitor with duration of action lasting 24-36 hours.

Duration of action of other PDE5 inhibitors:

  • Sildenafil: 10-12 hours
  • Vardenafil: 8-10 hours
  • Avanafil: 4-6 hours

Clinical correlation:

  • Nitrates administration can be done usually after 24 hours of PDE-5 inhibitors intake. But for tadalafil, nitrates are generally not indicated for 2-3 days.
  • Tadalafil can also be given at any time without regard to sexual activity because of the long duration of action (low dose).
  • Used in erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension.

Drug interactions: Nitrates cause activation of guanylyl cyclase → ↑ cGMP → relaxation of vascular smooth muscle → vasodilation. PDE-5 inhibitors enhance the accumulation of cGMP by preventing its degradation and therefore cause vasodilation. Since nitrates also act by increasing cyclic GMP, they can potentiate the effects of PDE-5 inhibitors. Hence, men treated with PDE-5 inhibitors and nitrates are at risk for severe hypotension and syncope.

Adverse effects:

  • The most common side effects reported include headache, flushing, nasal congestion, nasopharyngitis, and dyspepsia. Rare but serious reports of prolonged erections lasting more than 4 hours and priapism (painful erections lasting more than 6 hours) have been reported with PDE5 inhibitors. 
  • Sildenafil and Vardenafil also cause retinal PDE-6 inhibition and can result in blurring of vision and blue-green tinting of the vision.

Related Pearl: PDE inhibitors
