questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of schizophrenia, and on treatment for drug-induced Parkinson's presents with complaints of constipation, blurred vision, and dry mouth. Which of the following drugs may be responsible for the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient with Schizophrenia and drug-induced Parkinson's disease with anti-cholinergic symptoms is taking benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl). 

Drug-induced Parkinsonism is a condition that is caused by certain drugs that have D2 antagonistic action like typical antipsychotics. Due to the decrease in dopaminergic activity, they result in an unbalanced cholinergic activity. Benzhexol is a centrally-acting antimuscarinic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons. 

The following drugs are implicated in drug-induced parkinsonism:

Drug class

Examples 
Typical antipsychotics

Phenothiazines, haloperidol
Atypical antipsychotics Risperidone, olanzapine
Dopamine depleters Reserpine, tetrabenazine
Antiemetics Metoclopramide, levosulpiride
Calcium channel blockers Flunarizine, cinnarizine

Other options: 

Option A: Lithium is used to treat bipolar disorders and major depressive disorder. The main adverse effects are lithium toxicity, serotonin syndrome, and pseudotumor cerebri. Lithium use is usually avoided in patients with a known cardiovascular disease due to an increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias. 

Option B: Pramipexole is used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and restless leg syndrome. The main adverse effects are dyskinesias and postural deformities. 

Option D: Selegiline is used in the treatment of major depressive disorder and Parkinson's disease. The main adverse effects are serotonin syndrome, somnolence, and exacerbation of hypertension. Hence, it is not preferred in Parkinson's patients with hypertension.

questions.text: A female patient comes with complaints of swelling and pain in her great toe. Her uric acid level is found to be high. A drug which reduces uric acid levels is prescribed. Which of the following enzyme should the drug inhibit?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is a purine antimetabolite and an inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme.

Allopurinol is used to treat hyperuricemia in patients with gout. It also prevents the occurrence of gout in those with haematological malignancies about to undergo chemotherapy.

Allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (alloxanthine), reduce urate production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase. This prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine, and xanthine to uric acid, thereby reducing plasma uric acid levels. Allopurinol is also a substrate for xanthine oxidase. 

Febuxostat is a nonpurine inhibitor of uric acid synthesis. It is not an analogue of hypoxanthine. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase and it is indicated in gout management. 

Other options:

Option A: Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone. It is a urease inhibitor (urease generates ammonia from urea that elevates the pH of the urine that can lead to formation of triple phosphate stones).

Option B: Alkaptonuria is a disorder of tyrosine metabolism, that develops due to the defect in homogentisate oxidase, which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate.

Option C: Menkes disease is caused by defective lysyl oxidase enzyme.

Related Pearl: Some Examples of Suicidal Inhibitors

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is positive for SARS-COV-2. A total of 30 people have been in contact with the patient and show no symptoms or signs of COVID-19. What is the time duration for which they must be quarantined?
questions.solution:

    • Modified: selective partial limitation of movement

questions.text: Following urine microscopy and examination, a child is found to have hematuria and RBC casts in the urine. What is the probable cause for this?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of nephritic syndrome (hematuria and red cell casts) seen in this child is most likely due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN) is characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It usually occurs following a throat infection by nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci. It can also occur after streptococcal skin infection or pyoderma.

The typical patient develops an acute nephritic syndrome following:
  • 1 to 2 weeks after antecedent streptococcal pharyngitis or
  • 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

The pathogenesis involves circulating antibodies elicited by streptococcal antigens reacting with normal glomerular antigens, and complement activation by directly deposited streptococcal antigens causing the immunologic injury.

In this immune complex-mediated APSGN, we see the following in most patients:

  • Decrease in the serum complement (C3) level (levels normalize in 6 to 8 weeks)
  • ASO titer is increased (the titers decrease to low levels within 4 to 6 weeks)
Microscopic Findings in PSGN:
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration
  • Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or humps, are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

Below is the image showing light microscopy findings of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Other options:

Option A: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. Hematuria is not a usual feature of nephrotic syndrome and rather presents with nephrotic range proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema.

Option C: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) present in adolescents or young adults with nephrotic syndrome and a nephritic component manifested by hematuria. It is not frequent in children.

Option D: Minimal change disease is the most frequent cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: Which of the following cells is responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies in liver sinusoids?
questions.solution:
Kupffer cells, also known as stellate macrophages and Kupffer-Borowicz cells; are specialized macrophages of the liver that are responsible for the destruction of bacterial foreign bodies. These cells are present in the walls of the sinusoids and not in the perisinusoidal space (Space of Disse). They are responsible for removing cellular and microbial debris from the circulation, and also for secreting cytokines involved in defense.

Macrophages can be divided into:

  • Blood macrophages (monocytes) are the largest of the lymphoid cells in the peripheral blood. Life span: 3 days. 
  • Tissue macrophages survive for months. 

2 main functions of macrophages:

  • Phagocytosis.
  • Antigen presentation.

All the options given are various types of cells present in an adult liver.

Option A: Hepatocytes are polyhedral cells with a central spherical nucleus, arranged in a single-cell layer. Every hepatocyte has contact with adjacent hepatocytes (with gap junctions for intercellular communication), bile canaliculus, and the space of Disse/perisinusoidal space (hepatocytes project multiple microvilli into this space for active transport of substances.)

Option B: Ito cells or hepatic stellate cells are present in the space of Disse and store vitamin A. They are mesenchymal in origin and take part in the development of hepatic fibrosis.

Option C: Sinusoidal endothelial cells are flat cells with a central nucleus and are joined to each other by junctional complexes. Their cytoplasm contains numerous transcytotic vesicles. These are separated from hepatocytes by the space of Disse (perisinusoidal space).

questions.text: A teenager developed swelling of the face, lips, and tongue and also found it difficult to breathe within a few minutes of consumption of prawns. What is the type of hypersensitivity seen here ?
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis following consumption of prawns is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or Type 1 hypersensitivity.

Immediate (Type I) Hypersensitivity

  • These are also called allergic reactions or allergies.
  • They are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals
  • Activation of TH2 cells is mediated by IL-4 and in turn, TH2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13.
  • These cytokines act on B cells to stimulate IgE and activation of eosinophils.
  • IgE coats mast cells by binding to Fcεg receptors; reexposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI, activation of mast cells, and release of mediators.
  • The principal mediators are histamine, proteases, and other granule contents; prostaglandins and leukotrienes; as well as cytokines.
  • The mediators are responsible for the immediate vascular and smooth muscle reactions and the late-phase reaction (inflammation).
  • The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.
  • It occurs in two phases: immediate phase and late phase.

 

 

Image: Sequence of events in immediate hypersensitivity

Related Pearl: Disorders Caused by Immediate Hypersensitivity

Clinical Syndrome

Clinical and Pathologic Manifestations

Anaphylaxis (may be caused by drugs, bee sting, food)

Fall in blood pressure (shock) caused by vascular dilation; airway obstruction due to laryngeal edema

Bronchial asthma

Airway obstruction caused by bronchial smooth muscle hyperactivity; inflammation and tissue injury caused by late-phase reaction

Allergic rhinitis, sinusitis (hay fever)

Increased mucus secretion; inflammation of upper airways, sinuses

Food allergies

Increased peristalsis due to contraction of intestinal muscles

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with the following lesion on his face. He has a history of acne rosacea. The condition is:
questions.solution:
The image above shows an exophytic, pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation suggesting a diagnosis of phymatous rosacea or rhinophyma

Phymatous rosacea is a subtype of acne rosacea characterized by thickened skin and prominent follicular openings. There is marked nasal distortion with an increase in size and a bulbous tip. Rhinophyma is the most common type of phymatous rosacea.

Rhinophyma (potato tumour/elephantiasis of the nose) is due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous gland. It is associated with long-standing cases of acne rosacea.  It is mostly seen in middle-aged men involving the tip of the nose causing unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision.

Treatment of rhinophyma

  • First-line
    • Topical skin‐peeling agent if there are large occluded follicles
    • Electrocautery or laser for telangiectases
  • Second-line - Low‐dose isotretinoin therapy
  • Third line - Ablation of phymatous tissue with carbon dioxide laser • Surgical remodelling of the nose.

Other options:

Option B: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by gram-negative bacillus Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It presents with chronic granulomatous inflammation of the nasal cavity, causing nasal obstruction, discharge, crusting, and eventual nasal deformity.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. It presents with painless, friable, polypoidal masses in the nasal cavity, often causing nasal obstruction and bleeding.

Option D: Scleroderma causes rashes on the face but has no association with long-standing acne rosacea. It is characterized by skin thickening, tightening, Raynaud's phenomenon, and internal organ involvement such as the lungs, heart, and gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: Which drug elicits the following response on blood pressure and heart rate as shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The above picture shows an increase in systolic pressure, diastolic pressure and mean arterial pressure, and reflex bradycardia. This effect is seen in case of norepinephrine.

Norepinephrine acts on α1 and β1 receptors to increase the peripheral vascular resistance and stroke volume respectively. This causes an increase in diastolic, systolic, and mean arterial pressure. Increased mean arterial pressure leads to reflex bradycardia.

Adrenergic drug

Receptors it acts on

Adrenaline

α1 + α2 +β1 + β2 

Noradrenaline

α1 +α2 +β1 but no β2 action

Isoproterenol

β1 + β2 + β3 but no α action

Other options:

Option B: Isoproterenol increases systolic blood pressure by increasing contractility and increases heart rate due to its β1 action. The β2-mediated vasodilation, results in a decrease in mean arterial pressure and reflex tachycardia.

Option C: On administration of epinephrine, there is an increase in systolic pressure which is greater than the decrease in diastolic pressure so the pulse pressure increases. Heart rate is increased as a result of direct cardiac stimulation.
At higher concentrations of adrenaline with IV administration, alpha action predominates and hence a rise in BP is seen. Due to rapid metabolism and uptake, the concentration of adrenaline decreases, and the β2 action predominates. Hence a decrease in BP is seen. This is referred to as the biphasic reaction of epinephrine.

Option D: At higher concentration, dopamine usually increases systolic blood pressure and pulse pressure and has no effect on diastolic blood pressure or increases it slightly. Tachycardia is less prominent during the infusion of dopamine.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs does not require any renal dose modification in those with chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin is a competitive dipeptidyl peptidase - 4 inhibitor does not require any renal dose modification.  

Linagliptin binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system, with very little renal clearance.  

It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or as combination therapy with other drugs when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated.

Other options:

Saxagliptin and other DPP - 4 inhibitors circulate primarily in unbound form and are excreted largely unchanged in the urine. Renal dose modification is required in patients with reduced renal function.  

Repaglinide is a non-sulfonylurea insulin secretagogue. A proportion of the drug is eliminated by the kidney and dose modification is required.  

Glyburide is a sulfonylurea insulin secretagogue which is metabolised in the liver and the metabolites are excreted in the urine. Thus it requires dose modification in both renal and hepatic insufficiency.

The mechanism of action of DPP-4 inhibitors are:

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the clinic by her mother with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months and vesicles in the superficial layer of the tympanic membrane is suggestive of myringitis bullosa.

Bullous myringitis (myringitis bullosa haemorrhagica) is the finding of vesicles in the superficial layer of the tympanic membrane without affecting the contents of the external or middle ear. If the middle ear becomes involved, this would be consistent with acute otitis media. It occurs due to infection by influenza virus or by Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Bloody otorrhea can occur when a bulla rupture and is referred to as bullous hemorrhagic myringitis.

Option B: Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

It is often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss not exceeding 40 dB, which is insidious in onset. Speech may be delayed and defective due to hearing loss. Mild earaches with a history of upper respiratory tract infection are usually seen. 

On otoscopy, 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • If the tympanic membrane is transparent fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen

 The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss. X-ray mastoid reveals clouding of air cells. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration techniques. 
  • Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid, grommet insertion, tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy.

Option C: Acute otitis media is an acute infection of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. It presents with marked earache and hearing loss is seen in later stages. Otoscopy shows a red and bulging tympanic membrane. 

 

Option D: Myringitis granulosa is characterized by granulations on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane. It is associated with long-standing foreign body, wax impaction, and external ear infection.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of watering, redness, foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis. It is most commonly associated with contact lens wear. It can also be associated with ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles.

The patients usually present with redness, foreign body sensation, increased mucus production, itching, blurring, and loss of contact lens tolerance. On examination, giant papillae are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae.

Papillae are reddish, flat-topped raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva These are the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium.

The image below shows papillae in the tarsal conjunctiva.

Treatment includes removing the offending cause. Mast cell stabilizers such as sodium cromoglycate, and drugs like azelastine and olopatadine which have combined antihistamine and mast cell stabilizing effects are effective. Steroids can be used for resistant cases.

Other options:

Option A - Trachoma is caused by chlamydia trachomatis. In acute trachoma, sago grain follicles are characteristically seen as shown below. 

Option B - Follicular conjunctivitis has follicles which are greyish-white raised areas seen on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses. The image is shown below.

Option D - In spring catarrh (vernal catarrh), cobblestone appearance is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva, ropy discharge, and Maxwell–Lyon sign are present. Horner-Tranta’s spots which are discrete whitish raised dots along the limbus can also be seen. It is more common during summer.

Image showing Horner-Tranta’s spots.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

Strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (1–9 yrs)

  • Prevalence >10% → SAFE
  • 5 to 10% → FE
  • < 5% → NO intervention

questions.text: A public health worker is going out into the community once every 15 days for collection of blood smears for malaria surveillance. What type of surveillance is this?
questions.solution:
Active case detection is done every fortnight by examination of blood smears by house visits and it is a type of active surveillance.

Malaria surveillance system:

Active case detection: Blood smears are collected by the Multipurpose Workers/Auxiliary nurse midwife on house visits every fortnight.

Passive case detection: Detection of fever cases that report to ASHAs or peripheral health volunteers.

Surveillance: There are factors which determine occurrence and distribution of diseases and other conditions of ill health. These factors are continuously scrutinised in surveillance. Monitoring is one of the essential components of surveillance concept.

Objectives of surveillance are:

  • To provide information about changing health trends
  • To provide feedback which can change health policy
  • To provide public health disaster warnings

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to less than 1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Categories according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Definition  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥ 1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥ 1.   Same as category 2

questions.text: WHO defines blindness as visual acuity less than ______
questions.solution:
According to WHO, 'Blindness' is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60, or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10°, in the better eye with the best possible correction.

Presenting visual acuity in the range of worse than 6/18 to 6/60 is defined as moderate visual impairment. Presenting visual acuities from 3/60 (including 3/60) to worse than 6/60 is classified as severe visual impairment.

Distance vision impairment:

  • Mild –visual acuity worse than 6/12 to 6/18
  • Moderate –visual acuity worse than 6/18 to 6/60
  • Severe –visual acuity worse than 6/60 to 3/60
  • Blindness –visual acuity worse than 3/60

National Programme for the Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI). The levels of eye care, according to NPCBVI are:

  • Primary level: Sub-district level hospitals, community health centers, mobile ophthalmic units, upgraded PHCs, link workers, Panchayats.
  • Secondary level: District hospitals, NGO eye hospitals
  • Tertiary levels: Regional institutes of Ophthalmology, medical colleges.

The goal is to reduce the prevalence of blindness to 0.3% by 2020.

questions.text: A new drug is introduced into the market after which phase of the clinical trials?
questions.solution:
A new drug is introduced into the market after phase III of the clinical trial.

Phase III of the clinical trial checks the efficacy and monitors the adverse reactions of a new drug and thus a new drug is introduced after this phase.

Phase II takes place over a short duration. During this period, the most prominent side effects are assessed. However, less common side effects might have gone undetected due to the shorter duration and smaller study group.

Phase III takes place over a longer duration and includes more population as compared to Phase II. Because these studies are larger and longer in duration, the results are more likely to show long-term or rare adverse effects. Hence, this phase is used to monitor adverse effects.

questions.text:
A patient presented with complaints of chest pain at rest for 6 hours and ECG suggestive of Myocardial Ischemia. Which among the following is used for diagnosis?

LDH - Lactate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
Measurement of LDH1 is suggestive of MI as it is seen predominantly in the heart.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)

  • Normally, serum levels of LDH2 are greater than those of LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1 is more than LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio.

  • LDH: A tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (Heart) and M isoform (Muscle)

    • LDH-1: Heart.
    • LDH-2: Blood.
    • LDH-3: Brain, kidney, lungs, spleen, pancreas.
    • LDH-4: Liver and skeletal muscle.
    • LDH-5: Liver and skeletal muscle.
  • Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI.

The other cardiac biomarkers are:

Troponin T and Troponin I

  • These are the proteins that mediate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and skeletal muscles.
  • They are highly specific for MI.
  • Troponin I is more important than troponin T.
  • Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days.
  • This makes troponins a superior marker for diagnosing MI in the recent past (late diagnosis).
  • Reinfarction: It is now clear that cardiac troponin (cTn) increases rapidly, even if it is from an abnormal baseline in patients with reinfarction.
  • If the cTn concentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected reinfarction, the diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the cTn measurement

Creatine kinase (CK).

  • It is less sensitive than troponins.
  • When cTn is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acute MI.
  • If it is the only assay available, it can be used, but it is far less sensitive and specific.

Myoglobin

  • It is the earliest enzyme to increase after MI.
  • Myoglobin is a protein found in the skeletal and cardiac muscles, which binds oxygen.
  • It is a very sensitive indicator of muscle injury.
  • However, it is not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle.
  • The rise in myoglobin can help to determine the size of infarction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old factory worker was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed local spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of methanol toxicity. Ethanol and fomepizole is used for the treatment of this condition.

Methanol poisoning is caused due to ingestion of illicit liquor which contains ethanol adulterated with methanol. Methanol is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid by alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenases, respectively. The metabolites of ethanol are responsible for the toxic effects.

Clinically, patients present with headache, vomiting, abdomen pain, uneasiness, confusion, delirium, and coma. Formic acid specifically damages the retina and optic nerve and results in blurring of vision and blindness.

Elevated levels of formic acid and other organic acids result in metabolic acidosis in arterial blood gas analysis(ABG).

Treatment of methanol poisoning includes gastric lavage with sodium bicarbonate if the patient is brought within 2 hours of ingesting methanol to combat acidosis. Ethanol infusion since ethanol is preferentially metabolized by alcohol dehydrogenase over methanol and helps by reducing the rate of generation of formaldehyde and formic acid.

Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase and the drug of choice for methanol poisoning. Folate therapy with calcium leucovorin reduces blood formate levels by enhancing its oxidation. Hemodialysis is used in severe cases of methanol toxicity.

Other options: 

Option B: Flumazenil is the inverse agonist of benzodiazepine receptors and is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose.

Option C: N-acetyl cysteine is used as an antidote for the treatment of paracetamol poisoning.

Option D: Naloxone is a competitive opioid antagonist used for the treatment of opioid overdose.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination his vitals are stable, but he could not speak. He had no other neurological findings, had normal handwriting skills, and could understand what was being asked of him to which he responds by nodding.  Where could be the lesion for this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Broca’s area is concerned with word formation and is the most likely area to be involved as only speech production is affected here and all other examinating findings are normal.

Broca’s area is in the inferior frontal lobe.

Broca area processes the information received from Wernicke area into a detailed and coordinated pattern for vocalization and then projects the pattern via a speech articulation area in the insula to the motor cortex. This then initiates the appropriate movements of the lips, tongue, and larynx to produce speech.

The probable sequence of events that occurs when a subject names a visual object is shown in the figure and flowchart.

questions.text: A child with mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness was investigated and was found to be deficient for Hexosaminidase-A enzyme. She is most likely suffering from ____.
questions.solution:
Tay-Sachs disease is due to the deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase A which degrades GM2 gangliosides.

Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase-A. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down a fatty substance called GM2 ganglioside, which is found primarily in nerve cells.

Without sufficient Hexosaminidase-A activity, GM2 ganglioside accumulates in the cells, particularly in the brain and nerve tissues, leading to the characteristic symptoms of Tay-Sachs disease.

Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease are :

  • Loss of motor skills
  • Seizures
  • Hyperacusis
  • Macrocephaly
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Neurodegeneration
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness

Other options:

A. Krabbe's disease: Krabbe's disease, also known as globoid cell leukodystrophy, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactosylceramidase. It leads to the accumulation of a lipid called galactocerebroside in the nervous system. The symptoms of Krabbe's disease may include muscle weakness, developmental delay, and vision problems, but mental retardation is not typically a prominent feature.

B. Fabry's disease: Fabry's disease is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of a fatty substance called globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) in various tissues and organs. Fabry's disease can present with a wide range of symptoms, including neurological manifestations, skin abnormalities, kidney problems, and cardiovascular complications. However, mental retardation is not a typical feature of Fabry's disease.

D. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease is an inherited disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of a lipid called glucocerebroside primarily in the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. Gaucher's disease can present with various symptoms, including hepatosplenomegaly (enlarged liver and spleen), anemia, and skeletal abnormalities. Mental retardation and blindness are not characteristic features of Gaucher's disease.

questions.text: Which of the cells secrete surfactant in lungs?
questions.solution:
Type 2 pneumocytes secrete surfactant in the lungs.

Alveolar Lining Epithelial Cells

Two types

  • Type I cells – The primary lining cells of the alveoli (squamous epithelium); Helps in gas exchange
  • Type II cells  – Granular pneumocytes produce surfactant

Type II cells make 60% of epithelial cells in alveoli but type I cells form 95% of the total surface area because of its flat surface.

Type II cells are stem cells which help in replenishing damaged Type 1 pneumocytes in conditions like drug-induced pulmonary toxicity by amiodarone, bleomycin etc. 

Other cells – Pulmonary alveolar macrophages (PAMs/type 3 alveolar cells), lymphocytes, plasma cells, neuroendocrine cells (APUD cells-Amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation), and mast cells.

Clinical correlate :

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm neonates is due to insufficient surfactant production.
  • Lung maturity of the fetus can be assessed by determining the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin (L:S ratio) in the amniotic fluid. A ratio of >2 indicates maturity.
  • Shake test/Bubble test/Clement test: Formation of stable foam in the presence of surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol levels in Amniotic fluid.

questions.text: What is the name of the view in which the maxillary sinus is seen best?
questions.solution:
Occipitomental view with an open mouth is also called the water’s view.

Water's view: The patient’s head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backwards. The mouth is usually kept open while taking the X-ray.

Structures seen in water’s view are:

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with complaints of greenish frothy vaginal discharge for 1 month and a burning sensation in her vaginal area for the past 5 days. There is no history of fever. Vitals are within normal limits. On speculum examination, you are able to see the below finding. Which of the following kits would you prescribe to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing  strawberry cervix is suggestive of Trichomoniasis and the green kit containing Tablet Secnidazole 2 gm, to be taken orally as a single dose is recommended in its treatment.

Trichomoniasis: Infection of the female genital tract with the Trichomonas vaginalis protozoan

Trichomoniasis characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. 

The vagina looks red and inflamed. The inflamed cervix looks like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

Management: The CDC recommends one of the following treatment regimens.

  • Metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose (Standard treatment) or Secnidazole/Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose
  • The alternative regimen includes Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days
  • Metronidazole gel does not reach therapeutic levels in the urethra and perivaginal glands. Because it is less efficacious than oral metronidazole, it is not recommended.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: A 45-year old man who was a chronic alcoholic presented with confusion, ataxia, and diplopia. What is the treatment protocol?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

    1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :

  • Global confusion
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Horizontal nystagmus 

    2. Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:

  • Memory loss
  • Confabulation

    3. Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination of the affected eye, a relative afferent pupillary defect with a normal optic disc is seen. Visual field testing was done which revealed central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes, RAPD and central scotoma is suggestive of optic neuritis, specifically retrobulbar neuritis. 

There are 3 types of optic neuritis: papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis. The common causes of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease).

Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss.  Ocular movements are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be impaired. 

On examination, Marcus Gunn pupil or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is usually noted due to asymmetric involvement. The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecal scotoma. 

Type Retrobulbar neuritis Papillitis Neuroretinitis
Pathology Inflammation of the optic nerve behind the disc Inflammation of the optic nerve head  Inflammation of the optic nerve head and the macula
Fundus appearance Optic disc appears normal

Hyperemia and oedema of the optic disc with or without peri-papillary flame-shaped hemorrhages

 Macular star (due to exudates that form around macula)
Prevalence Most common in adults

Most common in children

 Least common type
Associated conditions Strong association with demyelinating disorders like MS, NMO

Weak association with demyelinating disorders

 Cat-scratch disease, Lyme disease, Syphilis etc.

 

The image below shows papillitis.

 

The image below shows macular star appearance in neuroretinitis.

Causes of RAPD:

  • Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)
  • Maculopathy (macular degeneration )
  • Optic nerve lesions (e.g., optic neuritis, retrobulbar neuritis in multiple sclerosis , anterior ischemic optic neuropathy , glaucoma)
  • Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction)

Causes of central/centrocaecal scotoma

  • Optic neuritis
  • Compressive lesion eg. Pituitary adenoma
  • Optic neuropathy due to
  • Poor nutrition
  • Tobacco
  • Alcohol
  • Drug- induced optic neuropathy
  • Toxin- induced optic neuropathy
  • Hereditary optic atrophy
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leukemia

questions.text: What is the health insurance package provided for an eligible family per year, in the Ayushman Bharat scheme?
questions.solution:
Under the Ayushman Bharat scheme Government provides health insurance cover of upto 5 Lakhs per family, per year. 

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission: To build a comprehensive need-based health care service. Dr R.S. Sharma is the Chief Executive Officer of the AB- NHPM.

Components: The target of the two initiatives mentioned below are to build a New India 2022.

  • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- These centres will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services. The first Health and Wellness Centre was launched by the Prime Minister at Jangla, Bijapur, Chhatisgarh on 14 April 2018.
  • The second component is the National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) which provides health protection cover to poor and vulnerable families. The Health and Wellness Centres will play a critical role in creating awareness about AB-NHPM, screening for non-communicable diseases, follow-up of hospitalisation cases among others.

Beneficiary Level: 

  • Government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • More than 10.74 crore poor and vulnerable families (approximately 50 crore beneficiaries) covered across the country.
  • All families listed in the SECC database as per defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to girl child, women and and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment available at all public and empaneled private hospitals in times of need.
  • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and day care treatments, cost of medicines and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number - 14555

Ayushman Bharat Diwas is being celebrated across the country on April 30.

On 12 December 2012, the United Nations General Assembly endorsed a resolution urging countries to accelerate progress toward universal health coverage (UHC) – the idea that everyone, everywhere should have access to quality, affordable health care - as an essential priority for international development. International Universal Health Coverage Day aims to raise awareness of the need for strong and resilient health systems and universal health coverage

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was on maize as a staple diet for a prolonged period. He presented with diarrhoea and lesion over his neck as shown in the image below. The condition occurs due to deficiency of:
questions.solution:
The above history and clinical features suggest niacin/vitamin B3 deficiency.

Excessive consumption of maize-based diets can cause pellagra. Corn/Maize has low levels of niacin and tryptophan. Jowar has high leucine content which inhibits QPRTase, an enzyme in the synthesis of Niacin.

Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia

The lesion in the neck is characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in pellagra. The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

Other options:

 

B. Zinc: Zinc deficiency can cause various symptoms, but it does not typically present with the specific symptoms described in the case.

C. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine deficiency can lead to a condition called beriberi, which primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system. It does not typically present with skin lesions or diarrhea as described in the case.

D. Iron: Iron deficiency can result in anemia and other symptoms, but it does not cause the specific symptoms described, including skin lesions and diarrhea.

questions.text: The number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births is called ___.
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality ratio is defined as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births during a given time period.

Other options:

Infant mortality rate (IMR) is defined as the ratio of infant deaths registered in a given year to the total number of live births in the same year.

Maternal mortality rate is the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age in a given time period.

Related Pearl: Maternal Mortality Ratio

Maternal death is defined as the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

  • Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths in a given period per 100,000 live births during the same period.
  • MMR = Number of maternal deaths in a period x 100,000 (or 1000)/Number of live births in the same period
  • Main global causes of maternal deaths are severe bleeding, indirect causes (anemia, malaria, heart diseases), infections, unsafe abortions, eclampsia, obstructed labor and other direct causes like ectopic pregnancy, anesthesia related complications, etc.
  • In India, the most common causes of maternal deaths are hemorrhage (leading cause), sepsis, obstructed labor, hypertensive disorders, etc.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: Which of the following structures marked in the image contains the splenic artery?
questions.solution:
The lienorenal ligament a.k.a. splenorenal ligament- marked 4 in the question image contains the splenic artery. 

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

Splenic ligament Attachments  Contents
Phrenicocolic ligament Diaphragm to the splenic flexure of the colon -
Phrenicosplenic ligament Posterior abdominal wall to the upper pole of the spleen -
Splenorenal (lienorenal) ligament Hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney Tail of pancreas
Splenic artery and vein

Left gastroepiploic artery

So during splenectomy, splenic artery is ligated at the splenorenal ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve can be injured, when a fracture is sustained at the area marked with the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
In the given image the arrow points to the medial epicondyle. Fracture at the medial epicondyle damages the ulnar nerve. 

The nerves related to the humerus are:

  • Axillary nerve is at the surgical neck 
  • Ulnar nerve is at the medial epicondyle
  • Radial nerve is at the spiral groove of the shaft of the humerus. 

Ulnar nerve branches and supply: 

Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

Injury to the ulnar nerve can be as follows:

  High lesion
(Elbow) 		 Low lesion 
(Wrist) 
Site of injury
  • Fracture/dislocation of the medial epicondyle
  • Cubital tunnel syndrome
  • Compression between the two heads of FCU
  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy (Valgus deformity)
  • Wrist laceration/ slashing
  • Guyon's canal syndrome
Motor loss
  • Claw-hand deformity
  • Hypothenar & interosseous wasting
  • Loss of:
    • Abduction & adduction of fingers
      (Card test - Positive)
    • Adduction of thumb
      (Froment sign- Positive)
    • Flexion of MCP joints
  • Weakness of wrist flexion (radial deviation)
  • Claw-hand deformity
    (more pronounced)
  • Hypothenar & interosseous wasting
  • Loss of:
    • Abduction & adduction of fingers
      (Card test - Positive)
    • Adduction of thumb
      (Froment sign- Positive)
Sensory loss
  • Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial third of the hand
  • Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial 1 1/2 fingers
  • No sensory loss over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial third of the hand
  • Over palmar & dorsal aspect of the medial 1 1/2 fingers

Other tests seen in ulnar nerve lesions are as follows:

  • Claw hand deformity
  • Froment's sign positive
  • Wartenberg sign
  • Palmaris brevis sign

The image below shows a positive card test:

Wartenberg's sign: (Weakness of palmar interossei), Sensory loss of palmar and dorsal surface of the medial third of hand and medial 1 and a half fingers.

questions.text: 3 months following cataract surgery, a patient comes with complaints of decreased visual acuity. On examination, posterior capsular opacification is seen. What type of laser can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given history mentions decreased visual acuity 3 months post-cataract surgery and the presence of posterior capsular opacification is suggestive of after-cataract. A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment.

Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

Treatment:

  • Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy: The laser used in posterior capsulotomy is Nd: YAG laser (1064 nm) whose principle is photodisruption. The plasma produced at the laser target expands and disrupts the tissues creating an opening.
  • Surgical treatment: Posterior capsular opacification is managed by creating an opening on the posterior capsule along the visual axis, a procedure called a posterior capsulotomy.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A 35-year-man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums and multiple ecchymoses. Lab investigations show Hb: 8.5, Platelet count: 12, 000 and Total leucocyte count: 52,000 with 83% blasts as seen below. The blasts are CD33+. The most likely diagnosis is ______

choices.text: Chronic Lymphocytic leukemia / Small Lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL)

questions.solution:
The morphology of blasts with abundant cytoplasm, fine azurophilic granules and Auer rods, delicate nuclear chromatin with 1-4 prominent nucleoli on peripheral smear and CD33 positivity suggest a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

The 2016 WHO classification of acute myeloid leukemia (AML):

  • AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 
  • AML with myelodysplasia-related changes
  • Therapy-related myeloid neoplasms 
  • AML, not otherwise specified
  • Myeloid sarcoma 
  • Myeloid proliferations of Down syndrome

AML is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. It occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age. Occasionally, blasts are entirely absent from the blood (aleukemic leukemia). Bone marrow examination is essential to exclude acute leukemia in pancytopenic patients

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia

The WHO system divides acute myeloid leukemia (AML) into several groups:

AML with certain genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes)

  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 8 and 21 [t(8;21)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 16 [t(16;16) or inv(16)]
  • APL with the PML-RARA fusion gene
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 11 [t(9;11)]
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 6 and 9 [t(6:9)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 3 [t(3;3) or inv(3)]
  • AML (megakaryoblastic) with a translocation between chromosomes 1 and 22 [t(1:22)]
  • AML with the BCR-ABL1 (BCR-ABL) fusion gene*
  • AML with mutated NPM1 gene
  • AML with biallelic mutations of the CEBPA gene (that is, mutations in both copies of the gene)
  • AML with mutated RUNX1 gene*

*This is still a "provisional entity," meaning it is not yet clear if there's enough evidence that it is a unique group.

AML with myelodysplasia-related changes

AML related to previous chemotherapy or radiation

AML not otherwise specified (This includes cases of AML that do not fall into one of the above groups and is similar to the FAB classification.)

  • AML with minimal differentiation (FAB M0)
  • AML without maturation (FAB M1)
  • AML with maturation (FAB M2)
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukemia (FAB M4)
  • Acute monoblastic/monocytic leukemia (FAB M5)
  • Pure erythroid leukemia (FAB M6)
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (FAB M7)
  • Acute basophilic leukemia
  • Acute panmyelosis with fibrosis

Myeloid sarcoma (also known as granulocytic sarcoma or chloroma)

Myeloid proliferations related to Down syndrome

Undifferentiated and biphenotypic acute leukemias are not strictly AML, but are leukemias that have both lymphocytic and myeloid features. They are sometimes called mixed phenotype acute leukemias (MPALs).
